Nokia Adds Exchange


In an effort to bring more developers to its platform, Nokia has started an ad exchange to pay them. GigaOm's Ryan Kim reports, "Nokia Ad Exchange (NAX) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeIB-aazqE046skn_ivNITkE4viG-fGCYzt7V1So0LQmpnkmDzmaXjkQEn-OrS21eOlPedHy1FiVt4TVt3jopm8PqUnddbM59aFlEDSikaNMphDP6jw956AhFNO4jKSn4P-dAvQ1850FbRQ==> , which is built off of Inneractive's technology, will allow developers to access 120 ad networks in 200 countries and target Windows Phone 8, Series 40 and Symbian phones but also hit iOS, Android and BlackBerry from one dashboard." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeIDejymTsFOimddcApZ5JCOXTm75ZMWB582LpUmsih6QzJqfN8cO4CpsvUn1Kbj1S_ztECpcwPQScHwzDcpgyS0MOi9cJdYaumvKFKoUwVJvHjOrMZffnt-7-NoSdR256exCy6Fqc13QpVXWzmvQb2rHdAxes-oEm6aS05e_9BYyIAzVl9496_Aha3-ritu4q5U=>  And, see the video <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeID7vSX4g5v-2dashY4ChoCYo9uYNh6Yjc_31iO0m-1nln98RBTbMjjkrWhad2ENZqOfKGi1a8LWTKD7vc7GDGDIIAJ0UeA7E7zIfkJnPei4LXdNZL_4PmbrKlYVNNPBHdX9a-UZmITNFw==> .

Retailer Ad Nets? Old News


The intersection of e-commerce, display advertising and retargeting has been getting a lot more attention since Amazon upped the ante with the introduction its third platform last month. But as Adweek's Tim Peterson notes, big box retailers like Best Buy and Wal-Mart have been doing it for a while. At the other end, ad networks have been ramping up their retargeting abilities as well. "A year ago, the effective media dollars deployed against audiences of other brands was effectively zero," OwnerIQ CEO Jay Habegger told Adweek. "Five years from now it will be in the hundreds of millions of dollars." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeIDT62B18RsIXpGbjGruIV3glyXiuhV03L4Fku45IwU-HoKTTRQndzytnbM8zXPGcoCfNQfujhCszRKwYcpwBH8BcnedM9iav5l4tjVuIzCWdrB3D6r8hGIIdUCfxznm1pPvjWVEw3GhI9M184_0xrsXCbwElOOzPk5_VlvnLSKGyg==> . 


Second Price Auctions


On ClickZ, Digilant's Nate Woodman reviews the second price auction model and says on exchanges, most are not second-price. Woodman writes, "Most of the research I've seen around advertising auction types is focused on the Google paid search auction. The common misconception is that the Google exchange is a Vickrey-Clarke-Groves auction <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeIDZLT86__QFdvV18UBiRKwhTcgkEspCfL5a4Qm3jZpJXaYKcHcpBzWLW3fLoTayCZCDwoqWh4g5Xc2z6vnBRff1AqIVEGF7fQ-tUXZQyuWAalmckagYH5CksqTtD51IiX0WeFy-aBYKJwdAKID4z6lGx0QjMYBFIbRr5Vqfhqc57lZ9l_Iz5c3_EWYqpYUUVYk=> , but most experts conclude that it is in fact a generalized second-price auction <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeIBbd0OjU87Tx8t--fik9lHERMw06tGXKmYi_UIVfRi1WH3yayQIvESxiOyTNzeI00rDOViCDpfVaP5yYYgbeR6XJvJyZdMpIftJGYbBfZJYz9gNkG9BewDroATliW6WdrFZrxEbhOaD1dAIAsNYtBVZ9Hen_uscIFg=> . Both auctions support some type of price reduction where the winning buyer pays slightly more than the next highest bid." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeIC9ZqBm_OsortxYkhExU7ERmbwIVUyOvBwK2Pv3BqrrL-s6_CLQLd3vvonB14KBN2LU2X5bZctMdhNHrSWSfLPYuomZ952PdnWWkLsCJMu8xqVqWSZ8uloVIt6HfCxPoi0R43nqKMSTuJBgJNnzhJUJ8KIubD0zZQQspkoFOa1XX4jXB71Ryv5c> . 


Toolbar In the Toolbelt


PandoDaily peeks under the hood of Commerce Sciences, a Tel Aviv startup focused on personalized e-commerce. One of its products is a graphic element that sits at the bottom of a website and pops up with messages, coupons, and other information. Ok, ok, it's a toolbar. But don't write it off, says Mick Weinstein: "Commerce Sciences calls it a Personal Bar, as it can, for example, produce different messages for first time customers versus customers whose behavior the software has already analyzed and optimized for." So far, more than 70 sites are using it and Commerce Sciences has "collected over 20 million user actions." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeIAAJ9BPW6pByUjnCaM2regE0sqdwlxTmujKXz3RZE6c0tWx4A2sNisOd3-nOPJn1NdI_-EnxG81mFvyUMg5xYdcb27EMX-b2Up2-Sab1nmmscPO_8w9W2-Fxz1Kkzgo-SQHn1Vt_hrG0jw0sJeWy9OAv9Iev48LvK7FuvkHL6lM0F-_vviKSu8mdtF4q4Cd8nnozTwzIqWopwZF8nBNiu4vghwnV5inZcP3X3GjyLm33qghoM9s_Sqb>  


Marketing Tactic Tumult


Readers of veteran NYT columnist Stuart Elliott are contending that a recent article <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeIDESIqXycTvm0xuKev0RPL4UoapzqnYJCp_rZchvvpvnvkTTA19nTj2nbUT0Sl8phK1AUbORYa7rNb7t9ESmz9vIAuEdjJVbSalQ6h6r4kpZ2C-YcobDLKRhMR77eEexc-BeOPzDYu7xwHxmYBlTaG6IBnMYfoO4WAW35WqfqPqgFLtZFQ65GtdmEoVuPvvyD4nJSEyn__tjdKIZWgUCp1bZ4GYu71uE4s=>  about Adobe's ad campaign, dubbed "Metrics not myths," appears a little too similar to an earlier brand promotion from ad tech firm's [x+1] called "What's your painpoint?" In a Q&A with readers, Elliott says he wasn't aware of the [x+1] campaign when he wrote about the Adobe campaign created by its agency, Goodby, Silverstein. The agency tells Elliott it never encountered the other campaign. "Is it because the internet and social media make it so much easier to see campaigns from around the world and share opinions about them? Is it because a connected world inspires those who live in it to see connections everywhere?" Elliott wonders. "Lots of questions, few answers." Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeIApFVPj9wyN1WM6NhAS_QP4ezlrsOfvv3UB0tWZbesEtYhTLDKLrHjIC044JzPaSz44E2ThMX6WIvBnmikj59wCgJTwLx3l5kQhxXraTeH1pliV63UCjMoXy0wuRIRWnTtKg2NEeXtVBT4EXJlCa2JKAguOerInorgfZuzk-4G2jAYv5lg8T1NLd8C_r3-XZIo=> .

Google Analytics: BYO Data


Google is letting site owners plug first party data into its core analytics product, via a new "universal analytics" offering geared to enterprise marketers. From its blog post yesterday: "The tools from the Measurement Protocol allow you to seamlessly send your own data about your customers and business (from any digital device that you are measuring) to your Analytics account. This can help you see how users interact with your brand from multiple touchpoints - phones, tablets, laptops or more - in one place." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeIBLO1dPWVQrT-6PLCEzjhAFLcGYP_qpntE2qnTZKR1Ul0lpEQV-CWzAHm0FmubppXM2GZ0U-VIJZNEy9ewkdiWGlXNxHVXdl1-ODwmsBjMzeQ2om879EOWtkfOC9EZpFdSq90spSCiLfhKl_r4MILO_cVK8q71KMyk=>  


Discussing Consolidation


On The Makegood, LUMA Partners' i-banker Terence Kawaja tells Matt Straz that consolidation is a good thing for the ad tech ecosystem. He adds, "We have seen a bifurcation of deals between top companies that are bought for strategic premiums vs. companies that capitulate and are sold for amounts that don't provide a positive return to investors. This trend is likely to continue as ubiquitous venture funding dries up and companies are forced to take action." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001MijKfQHXeICqVQp2Ha81a1MXd328hhzW8uvgWgF4bhJY13_px_0sir3dfMwQR3pB2vf0EK1-XDV6uykbmRakikG-1j75JStvLacPbJPcwJXujm1ed3fSEf2bhMeBJkbLZxz-4O8R4hQrMIO0n91aEUNsnAyotgqMWVY2flE-NelT5Y5MPXm7FEPSBBvyd47bsub0hPMWveG7K9a0GwN1vHbNzpMtLP-RgJm0o-eutbc=> .

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email? Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001h0Cn267O3xyA7ByUm0UAeTXBb-XCr0uPNqi0D-nY6wSwgGjJK9S98BAZEurJXfRnrDuU7f39ovB1VI7LfJBeecH68U_DykpaSE8p2_pCaunC7upbtXBmhbfaVs4lDVFK5J30wZUDlZQ=> .

 

Paywalls Suspended


The desperation for up-to-the-minute news about Hurricane Sandy persuaded the NYTimes.com and WSJ.com to suspend their respective paywalls by Monday. Poynter Institute's Julie Moos has the rundown of other papers that have put the paywall aside, at least for the moment. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001h0Cn267O3xyhqTFeP5fsYJPR7U69jt7GxRtb5nYadxu2vMPkt4INApbZ7E0rn1maVRjdKjScyB5ustCkV1Qfpf4STXxxV2c71ePzUUo--f0YGhUgMtHzcGKtifM5jSB1N7_4PhhVsX8UbNE8_75C4nj1KrFDb3zqi1HKwEs2VMqf4Q3PpXaMLt7pAGGHBsnHKblLUP-_DvykqsL-JpMjuDw5_KOlylJ2PQpCKr653d8=> . As we noted <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001h0Cn267O3xzjrvVVq9_uhhAvcBHN-CVUwPkpY65VKzmUNy7tokpZG_wmnhgDm_EvxjKA0fwy8qSuT2Wevs5k-ZUiTm4-UX99jeHEqCS1Gf6XP08bzcM3jjET7fbfYdDfVHSJrIQt6-yjh_Pv3HRoi6oKKJazW66RaPKZsRzOkUUlcKUsJG_FSxlUUJcgcqTtqGRJmKOV2N_Td9Yzq5OXbg==>  last week, the NY Times Co. reported that while paid digital subscribers were up 11 percent, digital revenue from ads were down slightly. While the company denies a connection, executives did attribute some of the decline to programmatic buying. Could the turning off of the digital meter generate better traffic and, in turn, higher ad revenues? Time will tell. 


Ad-Supported Activism


Facebook ads are playing into the battle over California's Proposition 37 in an interesting way. Ali Partovi, who has supported the ballot initiative to label GMO (Genetically Modified) foods, writes for TechCrunch, "The Prop 37 team had already cultivated a vibrant fan community on Facebook, which made all the difference. I helped start a promotion encouraging these fans to speak out for GMO labeling in their own words, and asking them to use the new 'Promoted Posts' feature, where anybody can pay $7 to increase the visibility of what they say... The ads are literally the voices of ordinary people. Our most effective ad units are not clever slogans or graphics, but fan comments." It's a tactic straight out of the content marketing playbook, but instead of just writing the ad copy, supporters buy the ad spots as well. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001h0Cn267O3xxRbowt40gmY6M13sCYxajgtrzaS7d73wgN7qanJWnwNS_LED5omJsr_mZSGbNksZkmwYc4YpR17VYCBi1ssqv0cD5xxwoJrbZlpS052U20ZX-cAo42rSAFefQjAnkqdP08o5rPeV9hvdH-g3Pc0DLeCcqR-izOdldmmow1oCccxA==>  


Get on the Mobile Train


In a 30,000-foot snapshot of the mobile ad space, New York Times reporter Claire Cain Miller describes familiar challenges such as low prices, "fat fingers" syndrome, and trackability. But there's momentum as well. Starwoods worked with Google on click-to-call ads. "After running these ads, Starwood Hotels' mobile bookings grew 20 percent in a month," Miller writes. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001h0Cn267O3xycSItv22j7uWKec9dOwG9GQXhBy83rv6fOE_L8mvHnEoljj9ifdMY8dbzamZ1LDNEHcXvTogaHQyxgqlR1M5VYTMcByz--5r50hlagh1zzA0MbbmrEua0yZYRfK1_RjK5cvAlP5qli9qCtsDCMwWN-bN872yMNZWD6wfKHf67q5lDys2vJTKtcIvhvR7KqbBjBS2-SyVW15RuTcsGu93Z9LX13-tRiIrRYziugiy2L3zSWYkScNo1rcMVPqomfJQ6XCcxShfNZu1eESMhyVOWK> . 


Gawker's Sponsored Snark


Okay, okay, Gawker isn't as snarky as it once was. But the site's content still has some bite and it looks like marketers are interested in working with Gawker on creating custom content (or "collaborative content" as the piece above says we should call it now). "All of our brand partners are attempting to get their story across to our readers in the most authentic manner possible," Ray Wert, Gawker's executive director for content told Digiday's Josh Sternberg. "And they come to us to tell that story because we know how to authentically talk to our audience. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001h0Cn267O3xx632xbi3farFN-6bwJNcJTJESgrZR5w9vu4gYhKzyzoapLHaxEFhw8bsritBE-nqT--hXvB4hbN7pAuMlCqpxbG9HO0eNlwqqn8djFv9J2JfIhpDRCZErNWCapN9yXs4w7PXc3Ym5hMjNw3xYlAB7hLuZjvdZwxWqtVrc8Fpxw2ks7kyh3Jpg0> . 


The Mobile eCPM Gap


There is a "widening gap" between the average eCPM of the United States, countries in Asia Pacific and Europe, and the rest of the world, reports Clickz's Matt Kapko, citing stats from Norway's Opera Software. Average eCPMs in the U.S. reached $1.37, ahead of the global average of $1.31 during the third quarter. "Google's Android devices continued to underperform against their iOS counterparts, but still captured nearly 25.7 percent of traffic," Kapko writes. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001h0Cn267O3xySHgMwL5eKJtvMM3vqWHkutwR3Op2-CvsmZialRLOJWpxvbcq5CFqmps0FpoAqvLW_m_M6Ls_Vj24kz8Gd3KOqi3ZHo5DqGS98VvT-3CS7fzroQriT0V7mkXw9Lx_hKWEdvkClxZNVSLU030fbI6grOPwuoAgGT7oq8CkkmRl3Og_937iDqQDALA4bw69Om5gaLBBWvUu66A==> .

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email? Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpeuKJW7djPrPG8f3m4Iuxf-XFV6G1KvppseZcuUJ3iDXcgfTkOKYWKDVYpAIvBEBsAU7AwHyZy_3ApTdylxtrwePcG-KQ7xDjb8nv5we5rkYwKmx65sxVwCo8wQiFNE7_a0=> .

 

Yahoo, Microsoft, IE, DNT


Yahoo isn't going to recognize Microsoft's Do-Not-Track (DNT) "on" signal in the latest version of Internet Explorer either. So said the Yahoo policy blog on Friday: "In our view, this degrades the experience for the majority of users and makes it hard to deliver on our value proposition to them. It basically means that the DNT signal from IE10 doesn't express user intent." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpetRIS3Z7c6eSFAZ9g_8c5fq9FlySLIYBd_mO5sWbC_QacPbcWmItpRkGZJMSRgKTU8th2fw8ttoYuWg2umV8VksJlMfBeGENRBtd9_s74gMTnmbHo7khwdOhaIu5vLqBhgWsdtlVmE7TSsFwDp3fgqf>  Industry participants continue to navigate between supporting a universal DNT initiative, responding to Microsoft and the public perception of "What do you mean you're not going to respect DNT in IE?"


Acquisitive OpenX


The New York Times reports that ad server and exchange OpenX will announce today the acquisition of JumpTime whose tech values publisher content. The NYT's Tanzina Vega explains, "Using JumpTime technology, publishers have access to a dashboard that shows, in real time, the value of each photo, article and other content on a Web page." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpevulCOqkJ9qhk4zDQJmhJAVHkedz2yqQQ5uUhaHPvsn3ZQrEnveMhhe3KrXi9niOv5D-jXiw-6Gu-Z3yLcoZH-kqkz7JLh-uuhixWzjPbIL8kEKpFUvlzE3QK5pgeYDrovtAzcVqu1NWYfv33hl5YX0bengW7Y_B5anp5XUOVteiru69y5ENwhE> . And read this PandoDaily article <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpeu_8iA_Lz5HSPg3zzs3dX4bateUOIvgfbXwAvSNXGv5_uBNMWN9IHoqREsHuzds-AI9GOVt3L7fCyW1j3fHyCJEzlFPldDzPYaosRHb2OSMaBRjjOZ2j5NZOm4s3M6_hc6h9wM4jz1-BbFEBUO675r3T3y3laJkr5KaqyLZ8m6SFjnSS8YUoWATdbOh9ThBj2sMiH748c4bmSw01dmdoKTSxzZFNkzvJXW1_VnePsvipQ==>  from June to understand more about JumpTime as 'holistic' yield management extends beyond the ad server. This acquistion follows OpenX purchase of publisher ad tech firm LiftDNA <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpetzjVLyEM41yJ7ky9dgzX1IQuPpYLlPKxPbPdMk13L6tYzMPENXDiLdHue_6CorJsARDOzu9FhOD-k_VVPyPpgPLrav5WhQqRMecjHda3-QQ1Uv0DE93bsGSpQGkR5xbZQ01nHlT-JlsGutvht_Xc2Gd0rlfPHSgDk=>  in February.


The Out-Of-Home Address


On MediaPost, Joe Mandese covers WPP Group's Spafax Networks which has developed a new index in conjunction with Nielsen for digital out-of-home buying. Spafax says it is a precursor to an "exchange-based approach" to DOOH. Spafax EVP Patrick Bonomo tells Mandese that the "new index will enable advertisers and agencies to identify a digital out-of-home media buy 'down to the sub-block level, based on longitudinal and latitudinal coordinates.'" Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpet4SaiLDUz7sO1Z4k1uEi1mFAaPfLV7YftFOAgBkVY2CfkWF_jWHlrl556ByYMwqHDBVTBfX8-MjP9nFONxBI1PB8vDQpcKD4E-4VZ4hv7abN6qoOfe9URktfEabTCYeHDX-dF0nlS8vLnCGa1Gg3DH> .


Apple Getting 'iLocal?'


Many industry observers regard Apple's iOS advertising as a barely meaningful footnote in an otherwise stellar product line, but BTIG analyst Rich Greenfield feels those views may be premature. In a research note (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpeudM16OpgoxuYCVArDs-4LlA-E6UM9fC6m5C-ODB6Gpl2kRTjixiHQ4Hx-kvk19Bc0R-YOS2v-FizmuLqScUjjRJzgySy05QI9OqFj679bcCRV2xXWL-GAinGQlEpgr2NbqXD-1rkkzigtSEkm6wuxu-4Sp0093KTP63Rdjk5djBiA_T7wIn65Hpmyt1XdnqveFtDlG0q7B5sQsfB0Otbkulsz5P3JQtiNdnFvNKHneayTftYDH5PI2> , he tells investors to expect Apple to make a big play into local advertising and e-commerce via an "iRadio" product. "Not only are Apple Maps and Passbook clear signals that Apple has meaningful 'local' ambitions, but inside of iOS6 (and the last version of iOS5) is an 'Enable Local iAds' setting that most investors do not realize even exists," Greenfield says. 


Marketing Move


John Nardone, CEO at demand side platform [x+1], is expanding the company's ad tools into other businesses, such as customer relationship management and other forms of marketing. "Audience-based targeting isn't just for advertising," Nardone tells Mediapost's Laurie Sullivan. "It's for Web sites, call centers and any interaction channels that brands use to interact with customers and create an experience." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpeux9Mw79QsFvLu9QE4FC0vqJSwapujH-XOQSuqZcNnl_RmBn2Vfw5cNXbJZh88sqiZ9auXSESJoGPmVDVCjHqgb0MX8FG_Jn_CE1a9WGk3Rs6nvbDWjaGrZhNReETRtkLZYA2lCEkMMldU5k2DpILr1MsAt2DQu0yDoFBzq_iEoZ8WSZv1lq4s0yG8G7DvCKXFdZFKq2p8C4fnHuhycarmEDXmG4Xydg2SH_QM8K_74lV2cZgxzwjljgbwxS4nJ68nK_mD6cN1etA==> .

Mo Pubs


Mobile RTB marketplace MoPub is lowering the barrier for entry to publishers... to zero. CEO Jim Payne tells TechCrunch's Anthony Ha that "the company wants to encourage as many publishers to use the MoPub Marketplace as possible. After all, he said real-time bidding is 'a better way of doing things,' and bringing more ad inventory into the system means MoPub can make more money from advertisers."
Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpev1Ms9wT-VayFRIalWAq4agOTPNiE01jtQBcV7YmMOZA3PC6Fb8jjszhN-v3DWCusoeGsoTlz4mGaEzgP76ILIS1RkLwnK6WFudbfssHEEdOiJHuW0xIwlMTzxLBMw8D1ZFE7EGyEyTijNk-EOtZnY0> . 


Relax Buddy


After a round of layoffs last week, some were projecting dark clouds over Salesforce.com's fledgling MarketingCloud platform -- built from the acquisitions of Radian6 and Buddy Media. Not so fast, writes Christina Farr. "After two acquisitions of companies in a similar space, layoffs are a matter of course. Logically speaking, this creates some overlap of personnel." There's more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpetd0njO5GMn1cQA-neOgboAN58Zr4b6Od2vPLfYRFt7vK0pp27FOsIXGtgefjBQUzRNxbh0HqQJ8FFm8BLZWK16qHZW3jHNeVQdlunUw-LcTcrF5hDHQSFPym_VBhOK6-26hFQPa6L4fagSYqRVXNlfRZhPcF6hG6deK6BjW6bYUw==>  


Online To Offline


The New York Times covers the roll-out of Google's same-day delivery service in San Francisco. Google joins others - such as Amazon and Walmart - who offer similar services. Think of the location and intent data available here! The NYT's Claire Cain Miller points out that this is not about operating warehouses for Google. It's about the messenger service between the retailer and the consumer at home. (The messengers are "the pipes.") Miller notes, "...Online retailers offering same-day delivery could make life even harder for physical retailers, because letting people own something the same day has become physical retailers' biggest remaining advantage." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpet2FmhDqqfPDLtRZdIN6TFLDMdcYsVKBsz8PPHTHrGwh4zEBOIWWN2LTuuvU0-RN6diYhFGjP0pnO7GZTlQ0XMLyeWuAh0YdcBve5wCJ6GM21yYOWgW8XvI1YK-_CoQ7m7HOEZKU03YADZMQHi3KP23jWAS5446SMeg2phVI8IIOdK2iGae_H-sSQcCKLAcQ0WwGhrYSpPze9Pz5j230wcr>  


Citi's Mahaney Fired


Respected Citi analyst Mark Mahaney was fired on Friday as he and a junior analyst have become entangled in a Wall Street regulatory scandal. Back in May, the junior analyst quietly disclosed his firms early findings on Facebook - pre-IPO - to TechCrunch. He was seeking feedback according to the filing. In addition to the firings, Citigroup has been levied a fine of $2 million by the State of Massachussetts which has been investigating the Facebook IPO. Read the filing by Massachussetts (PDF). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpesgy5faA8u-v7TrcaLm2tnniXrHuU0eIfN3aTRN7leYqYUxrA0o-zMH4QTdjNqg3fSPU64V_B0BnQM-XIh6tjuRWXSD9apucpcIXm0vIVQsVmo_OL_t0qc-UdjVK5HC6w11XNX0c---c6A1MBhctFrER5deYCh5Rl8=>  And, more here from Forbes. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpetUypZCwlbxBc-esviZl8iZY9_7pyGINzN1L12cr9IQlg5njKc04E2Y7gqJPraG8WDo4w7dzSzMCvBkerZElBGAct1O4iXO-WiHorwjDPKyse47Ag8D8YuJ6hf-Cj4qEE_Id4HoFqjRbVEXVl9Mr-bJE_C7K18hnPHKjfYRW8YTifnnkLi7y4AvL8K0K-EECdMQiOk61LjUx-3YIk3VotBx8d1BD8mwgTj7ql9wNsKJLg==>  


Amazon Dragged By Living Social


Amazon's generally positive Q3 earnings results were dragged downed by its investment in deals site LivingSocial whose value has apparently dipped. The e-tail giant was hit with a writedown of $169 million nearly two years after Amazon's $175 million investment in the Groupon rival, notes Mashable's Lauren Indvik. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpeu2Ky8jy9ncjOy6RWTEtq1nNcHYU9M-EIdlkZl9xTjWFW8PFBfWrOxf08KL8dmAPI3I0KrzI5wsP-JIHIZT2l69bEYIfJNw9jYckAwCScLAFplydySfmGX-KlnQajRahP-_NS9Giq3zwWUcK-xpF7ugLuX0vdRAVIU=> . LivingSocial CEO Tim O'Shaughnessy immediately looked to shoot the notion down of a "slide" in a company memo obtained <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpevhiAOonU9IpbQGdY8Yd3XQnIO9PC_qoCosX9_hF310zTZFjrsYvWepjyqcEcO-33nMG8UHCPyxeomDJXAYg4rpUADQAw6P5mZtA1NcKHXweu4rbLBTfrRuxk5cdu-uJN_tzBCzHq8O3K7DVENQte3mf43OIe7Il6jrEukJ-Z1J3xEtqsn-UU_UecdLrWfF5ZQT8ocKpEzfgQ==>  by Washington Biz Journal's Bill Flook. "In layman's terms, we took a charge of around $496 million because we had to revalue some of the companies we acquired last year," O'Shaughnessy wrote. "Those changes in valuation showed up as an 'impairment' ... but they do not affect the day-in, day-out operations of the business." Also - no significant mentions of ads strategy -but here's the Amazon earnings call transcript. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001LS6bbnwvpeuVLfYTaZQv6leApb8TMr25PRJag_65NcLdBwpnJs1C4m-6OrD2WqPt-tJE6oeCgGo6jdmA6R9XvxiHzjhjZFRoYSy6l3aYu2qMC4BLA5Ubr0tBGfRPH2QcfcYIUbBBe9CzM6dO3KAWvV6EFZ3Ke-4RG2R51OIv9-pi_v6S0QjHKDc6h206mv6d-WsL_YQUNImERSEldTrO1e6RorGKulB9>

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email? Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJofdDAmJMd_FefGwpvN_vzafzj6L-sQ1O-PuzE2ZU0V60mUgCOZp26HFo2Mh06ZeY0hTouRDT8TfkHCMys2RXcmwDgpaynFzzmbKd8JojDDBpErtACiafwtp7bf-buhkEE=> .

 

Mayer Makes A Purchase


After much speculation about what Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer's acquisition targets should be, the company has announced <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJqfJ50_C9gK2ZHyBihBAvyxCwmsKVLyM5sVhGLi4KfKgcsXRtiL8hKFOW0LYIIBAPf1c7dJ79d9APVIKzfLg1evijbZQCwo0Mhu01t6ZMqrlDQSlumBW6YM2MCCKlkyK4JS_M0ZdxadZ-F6njpgWGW7>  the purchase of mobile, social recommendation service Stamped <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJp7f4sJXzGL6ed-InG6EjJH5UX2pvebhytDatJ-T5SN2fQtuAudDh9ACaJ_4c3F-nRoao96jNVEhLYtWdlm6amw6-VzHgRC3do5T_ZZm6jbAg==> . Mayer's first acquisition as Yahoo's chief has a small ironic twist, as Stamped was started last year by two of her former Google colleagues, Marketing Land's Matt McGee notes. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJq6_I-BwcpfzXZnKStPq-Emu6mGjZ41cq2R_S9l9kNEdPV0aJ2KO8ZA0O5V6sYTsXf35ROhi4iFIqlabanvg1ZZPibIisrbksgNY_QJmfPMPjXtYXE1Zlt6BUa-Zh55Mi-3uHDcXP3A8RaBVA-VYhLmz-Lmttng4zPUoW3vJ_SNk2GGljgYak2sTOa84oDdJzUO1FgElqlpZQ==> . The deal price hasn't been release, but Techcrunch's Colleen Taylor cites unidentified sources who estimate Yahoo paid something "in the double-digit millions." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJqNaeZgrATXv6-0VW7wcKPNGoAUM92QBGpueoZXsELGKwZPIWFiXlE_2Im5LOqWh1KbtgFf0LVHjasYtcnqT7fZWxhdLyNc-bUkTzWCrqL1kn3J6c4fGLsXkxDF3BVez6_Zcc49URbdqCYJFR-yupMsRycRo4QGwXI=> . 


P.S., Marissa...


Darren Herman, the Media Kitchen's chief digital officer and a self-described Yahoo shareholder, has a lot of advice for the Yahoo's Mayer on issues of growth, pursuing a Big Data strategy and acquisitions. His "open letter to Marissa," posted on Business Insider, warns of tough competition from Google and Amazon, but thinks Yahoo's scale remains an asset. On acquisitions, he's dubious about buying one of the established DSPs or SSPs. If Yahoo needs something on top of Genome or Right Media, just buy an ad tech firm that just opened its doors. On mobile, Herman thinks no expense should be spared. "Why not go and acquire the mobile exchange portion of the Luma Landscape?" he asks. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJq5yTEsp9uI8cNzQsTWIf8ecY3BKHb8wAYQKkQ8MbAR5n5U_ro8cqdJOzqJD_p9fS11cG7Glbl9kPW5Klddcxw8V0shgFDfV5MiZekFMlEydfdn7AlTekVMQoK-kwaOaLpLBQURpJPDClnx7AR6AVkc5WIFRpr_gO-qdGwsEDV5QrUrJOecws8DEk-ECskB_4c=> . 


Facebook CTRs


Some good news for Facebook advertisers: response rates on Facebook have risen in the last year while average prices are down, at least according to one report. Inside Facebook's Brittany Darwell covers the findings from Strategic PMD Spruce Media. "Clickthrough rates are up 57.2 percent since Q3 2011, suggesting that users are finding ads to be more relevant and interesting. CPCs have decreased 18.2 percent, which allows advertisers to improve their margins while getting more volume from each ad viewed. And CPMs have increased 27.5 percent, meaning Facebook is making more money per impression." Read more.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJodlv_bsOgn6OLDrIBtiEg0PrL0sCtU9QqTHlupfsJK69Lr6tZ3pEDfG2P-2rXrduAbjuSfEVU-PrV7IutuYC92XTpBAVbET1Q_E83ysNCj2GPtLj6XRaXXWBjAUbPOa_iSbx43Qyc4bSkohQQ2R7vHClyH1kTh0OihaJXqUqLhByly7FJmApydKggmRtK_7fHWY4Xdd-urToDsHRR65XpcGtcP3Vd9yVg=> 


Dissecting The AdWords Funnel


In a way, Google's unprecedented scale and reach in search makes asking the question, "How does Google make money?" seem beside the point. But where it makes its money, primarily through AdWords, is worth a closer look. Larry Kim, founder and CTO of search marketer Wordstream, has taken a microscope to the ad budgets and performance of roughly 2,600 companies and used the results to create a detailed infographic on Wired. Check it out <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJqTPeeUlpbW9sL4YDeDe5eLXOTBTUDXdfcpVYHrt4Am4XtHLfotUEDyECUyYa5TxyCmYfC3iSzlpuSt5neR3j1NTSwsvXpMG0quUZZ5iDC029SFOxZhLhMb9xj4livpxro4lXRAXuhhaBOt7ApQkvkrFemLPOINmhdKsiES5cATOHsvcKfgRV2csgkuYI0KFbdFp9hUyLrDazB4xrc8Tun_MXK0qh6Y9Jyye2OCJkSWs2aRC3dZnT7OwZD0_pFwB3HFBYY7fCDBTynVYc1dIfozTwa_oYdxjxUmNCAf1ldQjfWRQXNORQ8LVr8wvIR9Q5qU1XwMXq8ySkp8V2uUXgprHQLFRt9xhBc=> . He also analyzed the balance of Google's revenue streams and concluded, "In the end, huge increases in ad impression volumes and clicks more than made up for declines in cost-per-click and click-through rates," he told Wired's Ryan Singel. Search Engine Land's Pamela Parker has more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJrDQ73AAMHL6ELAFiGbKenXbmUDyK9vFKPJgpgxkoly3op5nR72kk2Muk9ZSlrdxe816O4-r8VqvzSuzNJO2OVgfbwPvULfLezpS-B6TZC6FPYAM4c5fitJwRnCmCJa1tJxLGDVgoJGbdIAFJ4gKjuZ6klTyjTJbAJ2yLuM7ZhkRrTeN4EkeYnfgzR5pafL2A8=> . 


Hiring A Rolodex


In a think piece on The Makegood, MediaMath Sales Director Ellie Windle discusses the challenges of hiring a sales rep in ad tech. She offers an anecdote: "Their background seems like a great fit, and they are name-dropping like Kim K at a Beyoncé concert. There are few red flags, but they seem to know all the right people and you need to fill this position ASAP, so you make an offer. They negotiate an insanely high base, which you pay, because by now you think you have to have them. They join your company.. and do not sell ANYTHING." Don't hire for the Rolodex, says Windle. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJqxPueBesFrtIX3oPNAZHXfRyAriXtNDPl5onppM5qXqLgW1i9gSnSq44r1jrX4QgJK1V_fsQaVNIuEe1XPhOg5-Fvp0H2Pdnp3WbFexyHmsDBS0_UZZJN5yGHVZ7L1BAXeOGfGBT3FLb9CtxCI8XuvDmRQ0iZieiGn8gJd2sOsSH-PF_NtlZnp>

Pay Packaging


Former Right Media CEO Mike Walrath pauses from his post RMX-life to review the pay package recently filed through the SEC for new Yahoo! COO Henrique DeCastro. Walrath chides media analysis, "Is it a rich pay package? Hell yes. Does it come close to guaranteeing 62M as much of the reporting on the package suggests? Hell no." Read Walrath's breakdown of the package. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJr_0-i07Q7X38JDGbkukgzDexGOa_198qTCDb0QOijIefHgqQLlde1GIc5gtr96ZkVoqz2WnsnO5aLqn7faFzzT5YfZ47T_P8nBYF9kMGla76Q39bMfPPA1_AzEVrvgfRGYW1KXI8JLKMAV7grDmOkn37gD9aJlHxE1MNJ-0gMDTF3T5BA4N16On0xbh9OOdgrnWHrs6wtCTA==>  


Optimization Primer


AppNexus is pushing out a white paper that aims to "demystify display optimization" for performance based ad buyers. It covers points such as "translating goals into spend," "calculating valuation," and "letting the algorithm learn." Download the paper.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJrubi8tjOnJrSykNShTTuyYpB7PnExZaLQ-H_UXHAs2A4voNidvpZE0Qbrv2X1n0rOXeUwbbhWRXsGTuy_IGhyZpc6KxSnql-cfZQIxhGPxaDf8gTsKzEg_X5iJrD5mc5X1CzHmx8IMGE1WjqXpy6l7mVqEd8dQ7aMgxxhR9DkV8KsdLbh2YX5f0wb5gvGW4nH1aT_IDNs2VHaReWBA5RTulheIoXHsVcM=> 


Studying Audience


At the recent Digiday Agency Conference, eXelate's David Fischer provided an overview of a recent industry audience targeting study made in conjunction with Digiday. Among the insights he shared, "While most marketers tend to talk about data as one homogeneous mass, Fischer said that there are three kinds of data: third-party data, custom data, and validated data - data that is 'validated by industry organizations to eliminate inefficiencies in demographic data and optimize audience clusters.'" Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJpgRJPo74T4NtBQ-lzwtG3i4V68l4DJWEdA34YoynpY7u60DvvhaAzGffCK3SZ1mmMesqfeTDlEmyHTQ9dJNtCS0tjlTdFsa4mKVnJo2fwCFAtGd9AC07NFq1STXcVRzrrMeRMNpM68SBQYVHtnLrFWAarye_L7RzIgWUsesw9J-6Kb57cegWb2> . And, you can download the study here (PDF). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001j7cmo0MXnJrSYPBBFLKEG9oZjJ0oVsz2icWm79kyR5XtURdR6U5zohODIXxWMnKoU6W6n0O_JsqKc4_p_rilwDzn1hkCcVnNVHz28LyNXSXxVrbl2Md4YyfjkZAKz_h8DmXdKpHG-ZJcDRtxCIpntS1w5a_yILRLi696bBYCLXdu3Hi-sTgA3llEM7CVulUU>

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email? Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bQpqi_Iqyceb0Qx656Q9CwHl9-JaNsts8WD9dI-O8khS7HYusIn6VBTSBYzR60a9DpE4coZ6USwSb7--N2ir-2AZ2h7WKS9mNMrd8dN-f5UbiojYcGhxl_KfGhQEmLa2tQ=> .

 

Invite 2.0 Leaves Beta


Google is taking the wraps off the next rev of its demand side platform. DoubleClick Bid Manager, formerly Invite Media, has come out of beta and is now available globally in over 40 countries. Internal usability studies "show that it takes 18% less time to carry out common tasks in DoubleClick Bid Manager, as compared to Invite Media." See the blog post <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bQmnTs0eWn84BiSI0AhMnfSkWwJMQQi5aKhn-VUDCBJcNv7wmYVpAfzyk3xSjHJH5JByUoXRLYXA4Z4LmYhccZ32OypXWIEVc-IMefnBe5psUBRXqs-3Z4K6qmmIYnmwGvk74yv_Cr-EKH1tx1bneutIpABcJJcR8U-oJ_nEGx30FVu-NdCtxooSCRGLa6PMT8=>  - with a video from the product crew. On the PR front, once again, Google is making an effort to highlight their product team members and have them tell the story, rather than just Neal Mohan (not that there's anything wrong with that). Tag Manager <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bSfIq4--tdNnMFFlHLqDmOZWggYErK-POPbKqYf4-W7DJtSXpgU2WgJh8aa537K4fm9rFU5DVog9tlaXsbrf1Qpwr4kNNPBE0DsP5OnR-B8W54lyGlgM_GfdoG0LC4tI2K9ZymOjQFflaoieajfpnaeb1h_vuYDnvY=> , Ad Verification <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bTS3o2d-vAUUXc0yWagwcqHGM1OK67hjCniyQ_06QfetukhVIWtp6dN7Tj5RwseQ2tgjd3-kJNXI-9gDlIh_jJUFt6sBAOvfzS-91S9QSOIU6dNwA7OhMiqbKFsLcTySUgmOmoGRGRV3sXzRrYy1toERwTfti9BqwzFVBZNwUPEcg==>  and now Bid Manager PR efforts all highlight the teams. The message is being sent to current and potential clients, "We gotta lotta product guns here. Innovation here we come.""


FBX In Review


In a note to investors, BMO Capital Markets Internet analyst Dan Salmon lists the takeaways from a roundtable discussion last Friday (and prior to this week's FB earnings) on Facebook Exchange (FBX) with Rocket Fuel's Eric Porres and Peter Bardwick and x+1's Ted Shergalis. Salmon's key takeaways from the discussion: "1) FBX revenue is unlikely to be material in 3Q12 and 4Q12 2) ... panelists thought that FBX should eventually overtake Premium and Marketplace as the dominant sales channel; 3) although they were clear they are privy to no imminent changes, the panelists suggested that cookie matching is a possible next step for FBX ... 4) low prices, guaranteed viewability and brand appropriateness were cited as key advantages of FBX; and 5) ... advertisers are no longer buying ads to drive the number of 'likes' for their brand pages, but instead focusing on ROI metrics." 


Video Links


In addition to developing its mobile marketing <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bS3XAv9ISAF36RGCEwVnTbThcuPVE3Ut6XfOkztvjentQT4Pmahs_crV8wmp4BLM5t4UXinFQDw9FrjrjkW4uOXUMIXsrWO2tvteGC2X2877HZey_fahmej2I9VrWznrjv17-OC0GVq6dCw3BK8UFpDIO-QF_WHCsmkJCZiBkXXkOkm9wSkclMQde-ILnrVH7gDJly-C-4u57ODQJIGHqlgpA_jduS2rP8=> , LinkedIn is now expanding its video ad serving offerings. Video ads will appear in standard 300x250 ad units across LinkedIn's pages and will compete for impressions similar to how traditional text and image ad formats do, says LinkedIn marketing solutions exec Will Hambly on the professional socia network's blog. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bSn4PSvmLPrt_JJxbX3Qj8Mc7W8lUnZ_R_loo_AsZf_27mf7ooN3lT5IKHABqQ6JreKaFqvWySmGD9MytATjMme41i0ilC9cAAMOEh4YmfQsm-2hkJ-KF4VUNDdTR4MjOYRZ_TydmIaug==> . "With LinkedIn Ads you can control your costs, pay per view or click, and stop your campaign at any time," Hambly adds, noting that the videos are also seamlessly linked to YouTube as well. 


The List


If you haven't seen comScore's list of top ad networks (pay for play), things have gotten more creative as now there's a new section titled "Syndicated Ad Focus Entities" for players like ShareThis, Outbrain, Glam and Federated Media which shows their reach as measured by comScore. See the rankings for September (PDF) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bRb-VUVKhXm0WDb2qhGXJpfpE7Yb17-n22_160TEepJtyRGV_ZYu3soaJiNGmnI6NgnRx3u2guCK1DzY-UgJ4QSrJby43Mnwb0uZRl1aheIPNyTGOoivFTrcOBN4tdp_J1WvdPNc_32bkOB0NZCd9gPT2xzUaCkNrgFDiwJYu96z9zcfbwHrI4rRX_hXB4gNAwQw8yBAm3MX13Ah8g-BvABgE7pBHyhr4jNK67iwCVSR4ba5o3NDhp_PhZtRBsF35g2ug_-dInoIvaDaYQGbIxjE_6rIZBrnt4p6OuasRWpoOLt4BJqgl5x56MuAWhsdLG5Lv1MJnvQsA==> . 


The Big Data Economy


With unemployment rates hovering just below 8 percent, there is at least one bright spot it in these dismal times, and Mediapost's Laurie Sullivan cites a Gartner study that says there's plenty of work in Big Data. By 2015, Big Data will have generated 1.9 million tech jobs in the U.S. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bRAstJDi8kDHeCzE38x-sls8nurMJgcDfPNsEuJdX95LUtIhHuSm9DTc-ZXsG15zpmo8UqQrpnZ9mcek241He9YvBKlSI44NzDrkj3pJAkZoatQu3OOZ2na98lHP3px46Zf2Hm6Kp90j5bqZFbupn1SY7KxtxhAKF-CVOdcYDa2IzI1s1-nR1bobB9udmNUPMX3Tedf-Pza8A==> . Meanwhile, Gurbaksh Chahal, a high school dropout and founder of ad net Blue Lithium and social marketer RadiumOne, advises young people to skip education and just start a business. "There's an art to entrepreneurship," Chahal tells CNBC <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bTIMWdQeHMtylUZRa8uVloaQefA5dKmV5-YpqwOwHSmgx6sUajcdznXi14hatu_PV-WPicaha9KjxAMya1HsKJAHPECEWZtIbpa5yC9_OX9Lc5X-0EfSMDq> . "You don't necessarily need an education for it. You just have to be able to learn and apply the creative juices that come to you."

Ad Tech Industrial Complex


Upstream's Doug Weaver is warning of a menace to publishers: the Ad Tech Industrial Complex. Lulled by the promise of greater efficiency, publishers have given up control of their sales to ad tech firms who do nothing more than reduce friction and cost, Weaver says in his company's blog, "No company or industry ever saved its way into massive growth." He adds, "So the publisher and sales leader are still scratching their heads and asking, 'Is that all there is?'" Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bRPC0MeTMqceh_lFLEG6YEYLheLjxw28xA7LNTAXcVXZ87QCWDnPpWGYRqjDDnzCdraXHqjoniJGf2cADijaOS-AF6qXO9_rByPbEXBqntD91WkwqQg_rznaC4ciMYw0P0=> . 


Facebook's 5X Rule


Question: What does advertising on Facebook get you, versus purely organic content distribution? Answer: Five times the reach, according to comScore. The researcher finds, "In a selection of the 100 top brand Pages on Facebook (selected for having large fan bases and high levels of organic reach), those Pages using paid media reached 5.4 times more people on average than those who did not use paid media." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001jDAIe-Un-bQNQVBdr8vX5nu9xgeF-BbAK0Q42sPefbBdIIF3lV5Q8qzahY1lw1lNE4XimybU7cdJg6H3SSG4TdSK5VaVLvCcoCYFSfgvQ325uAFAS4UdtXdyGyUiZzs0FE_IjRrT0pA6wo0oTHNIblHPF5gYH5cet3KwBN3-s4t3pEooxWviPckoavHJHq0P>

Adding The Sell-Side


In Europe, marketing services company Publigroupe is going end-to-end as it announced the acquisition of 85% of the shares of sell-side platform, Improve Digital. Improve founders Joëlle Frijters, CEO, and Janneke Niessen, CIO, will continue to guide the company as a Publigroupe "independent entity." Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_nt_FJ7D1QP7HrE6BeDVCUt9g5VvhB_JupnjIaK9TmAXTgAm9V0-x72nrC1PwSDu5HLxb2LDIqATspOtlJc2-AknSUiL-RMDiO6DQTaFRgyGaJdvKSrCNobBKIIVJ1EGdvLvyA6Mjj0DoeCGvhLHRWPeNTiloSh-Ehe1YlWVkXmatT8gLm6tgfxZS0V06drsjuuhcb5gxiw1w==> . In April, Publigroupe signed up for a joint venture with demand-side platform MediaMath and formed Spree7 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_l-hXlMVxwNDMIijMuY9AGgB2fJRm51mLpeXSpJQoTdOUWGz-4l2qs_AJujkrJab2_kzR-ggspXaFV77jCivy7eZt8nDV3UND1gHC-Y7OYrrGWRc4H6gLXG9m3bxxCL3wX9RSmj__-45yIG0KvUx-y79lNs0UZ4hHA=>  to enable programmatic buying for agencies. 


Retargeting The Second Time


In a Magnum Opus of a Tumblr blog post, former CEO of One Riot and current Walmart international mobile products dude, Tobias Peggs, writes about the future of retargeting. This is what ends the post, "What I've outlined in this blog post is a small step away from what was envisioned in Minority Report... and you could pretty much piece it together today (replacing retina scanning and billboards for a Twitter ID and a mobile phone ;). Sure, there are plenty of holes and inaccuracies in what I've outlined - but that's why it's a blog post not a business plan. What i do know for certain is that there are smarter folks than me who are thinking more diligently about this space, and building out the required technology platforms that will turn into humungous business. The first time I was retargeted on Facebook, I thought that was magical..." Read about the second time <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_mj_LFs9A3jI1RjmM1_EOd0Ht4OuWVmdxEUGhxrLkPO2DvQtVGRslHNCpyHybkYyUG_5ihRA0kxYj43uca18m7mJOYhdG3PczpZx5-ez_-2R-4N3cvBygY4z8DIDhCHv-Mr8ciYYIkkDGoG-Gl03_9v4kCHD96AGQ7ZqAXcmKF7XEJXrN8ssTkbLv8Q1TAESXh5QE-GOODZ4JSU66v10ueo> . 


Microsoft Gets Clear On Data


For all of Microsoft's pronouncements that making "Do Not Track" the default option in its latest Internet Explorer browser was a sign of new openness and transparency, the Congressional Bipartisan Privacy Caucus had other views when it came to the software giant's new Terms of Service, the NYT's Edward Wyatt reported. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_la_iIprUpgjaswQtZC36UniQb_404FA260fudl0SDFz1G1geJNrEdGn0rdnin7KRHOqM7sOF883t75qnE6x7kmRf6xHRX1l9JSHLPvNsi8zc-PaTxBNN1IpE6dQvN9we2yj3D8Yv0wt0IeU8nI5_zUne4eUX-AW7-ODlDOKKRK-fitOGoCD4v4zirEQ8x8T1jON7Ze5QwgDYSCGgX7oiM5> . In response to Congressional concerns, Microsoft will now explicitly tell users that some of its web products would produce or promote targeted online ads, which remain outside of its browser. "One thing we don't do is use the content of our customers' private communications and documents to target advertising," Microsoft said in a statement. 


Deal Details


It turns out Salesforce spent a little more than the previously reported <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_k7PPqcB5s5ZAskPsAj5Q4__4Dr7K6BUq3US4Gsy0y7plaGuYLHvVtAplagBPVR2hPbxMgJBrCfvP8lqoQZ8RH8AnB1vgQTGjbL95ljw9ltjR39RgOgybWWb2uJNZ1_A2GZK8vlsfGsYs2Lp7Jw13ZsBuWIVE9SXzCz18vcIDbqI-Fkz0mw3iAiqMoPZ9CWRHoeTxYequ25id5P3qN9cMUe>  figure of $689 million on acquiring social media marketer Buddy Media this summer. AllThingsD's Arik Hesseldahl has the details from the company's 8-K filing <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_nOf_CbOQPbB2Q5k4shaIdzGvrkz5VxO2YZvhJnsj-_w7Kp9620008RbJTSV2uE55HhoMW125uVMM0ZsSWxpw06EvK5ZDkLoLHZG8qatJr7ZGh7gYzmDuhGLpAr74zMg0QWC2Ymx9-SnrXPlvN7coE1BX_iZk4NdKtOcTK9HUp0ZN7zKQ61bvxFg8_N-dYjKyg=> , which shows a closing price of $745 million. Still more: "Among other things, Buddy Media generated $18 million in sales, with a loss of $20.6 million during the first six months of 2012, giving it run rate to between $36 million to $40 million. "Remember that [previous Saleforce acquisition] Radian6 was, at the time of its acquisition last year, doing about $50 million annually," Hesseldahl writes. "Assuming that it has grown since then, when combined with Buddy's run rate, the 'marketing cloud' is already a $100 million business." Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_lzr9d5vQSMGzepihEluiqNkxqvfZ8BGwV8gllV_B6eYGLojhjPNj8B9tk9lflWpyTse2YXUqM6uEsabRBMJQwKALjotfXR4vtr0As0I4-esbL4KsgQZoBvqLTgIGAdspBJGAO-Oh8KRzU-Llas5EFKNagKba3PD4tsBVc60pywG1IIFm8Bj2QMWVg0IAUI35P2C812R2PAAA==> . 


Online Video And Its Discontents


Along with mobile, digital video has been one of the fastest growing areas of web advertising the last few years. The problem is, no one outside of perhaps YouTube or Hulu, is really bringing in self-sustaining dollars. Digiday, as part of a promotion for an upcoming conference, spoke to Deep Focus CEO Ian Schafer about the opportunities and lingering frustrations with the medium. "We're still looking at interruption as being the key driver for online video," Schafer says. "I would hope that we can figure out a way to get beyond that." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_kPNeY2XQqN2FLNwuUy3mMig9yNmlIj4ksY3dRiM4WnuhG1aL_RZ0FhnjPHI_jH7SOayR8rpcC8CwmBz9CIKwpkJCdYWpV5o9vOLCJ36yKDU2DETAHj65-YTPqO29hupx7k5jLYvoGl0VZtvMh1SkwwRF_eLWdJ2Qg=> .

Not Waiting For FB's Mobile Model


Adknowledge's AdParlor unit is a Facebook Strategic Preferred Marketing Developer, and just ahead of the social network's Tuesday afternoon earnings, it said that they are now offering mobile app installs via Facebook on a cost per install (CPI) pricing model. While Facebook barely has its mobile revenue model out of the gate, AdParlor is banking on some big moves over the next few months, even as mobile remains a fraction of online ad spending in general. "In initial tests we have run using this ad unit, we have seen consistent CTR's between 1- and 2 percent from engaged users," said Kristaps Ronka, CTO at AdParlor. In other words, it's a start. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_n9ETmK7wQVxgvYA2T3MswzigQ49Z4TkwYAccXYyhJzdUT_QdJn_ZTQ4m2SbuCGCBi400_37mZNiabEPQEajAsl86C1ZYVu4UydnC4VwiUbYbQg7pvWCtjHcx_XXDUDtr09lUCwLQODh2gFXSHJMoTi7MbkfHmcy6qNLY7oj2d4EnfAJRI5m8ws> . 

Hiring Spree

Media buying workflow specialist Centro has brought in two digital ad veterans as part of a larger growth strategy, which is predicated on better ties to the agencies. The two latest additions are Scott Neslund, who most recently was president of Publicis' Moxie Interactive unit and is now Centro's SVP for media; and former Undertone marketing chief Kelly Wenzel as its new CMO. "We needed to get our software to a certain level of automation before we thought we'd be ready to go big," Centro CEO Shawn Riegsecker told Mediapost's Joe Mandese: "That time came when we came toward the end of this year." Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_lixsJoTgcrc2npqsp5PfPRTKGmcKMoGaC6JiGtvsOTifXO6suxjIYALwCvf05K1CWyJicd-uQJGb0ja1IH7XZ73Ylmrf4EjjMPwQqINGg2w8eTklnpiuznTQd1QW8P2QjqGiT3lk71bFUelc5f4awmU6T3F1KFcmFnDwfAlwXtU_H8T8nnqOLLoTws7zUVZjpM4hP45GqBgauvbms2Qd0eZd2ijel40v4=> . 


Audience Nodes


Interclick-er Jason Lynn makes an appearance on the Yahoo Ad blog and talks about his company's Genome audience buying solution. (Yahoo! acquired Interclick a year ago <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_nnIqHlA01lrBIgxA0fqClLrHRVwTyeT9Rmql9Wm_tGZEHGsDTpXsp2q_fAQmH9byFd-plDjFxzyL9W8aW9JSGqMzJsfYskf2PWGVUDANMDcjgt_IVy2prhvWHn786Yhpp3UoVMOZR3CClVIdglZEk1tN6SvjS1-qk=> .) Lynn talks about Genome's 'brain' known as Online Segment Manager (OSM) saying that it "currently has 1.5 million nodes, or unique data facts, such as 'BlueKai Sedan Auto Shopper' or 'Yahoo! Sports Enthusiast,' which can be leveraged against any of our clients' campaigns." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_m38PuJpAuGAaoKHO5owK4em-2zpd8k2VRNbi-og4oj4AbmUH_w03yiEJY4AIKabkDRJYQmYxU6KOaI8JnqyUH8mPo92QbO1im-k3lFUmYCuNFXONlxMjXKMTzzUm9pAYoVcJ7j6QQAS46TDt-nUX0Nrx78_KRSVr5EXVlPNqfj_YOhsodxM5kH0bwb9_G23PGeWy2UKy2wSfo6om3G0W6R>  


Mobile Future Is Now


Digital marketing company AudienceScience isn't waiting for mobile advertising to catch up with the wider online ad market. To get a jump on things, the company is introducing mobile targeting tools into its Gateway offering. "We have a trove of unique data points that are only available through the AudienceScience Gateway, pointing to IAB stats that showed mobile ad spending accounting for only for 2.1 percent of Internet advertising. "This number is expected to rise to 15.2 percent by 2016. We are offering advertisers a powerful way to target customers across devices and channels." Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_kSbqvQYIa1ZTZAA1918as4oaD4ofyrtl37gczlB43lOk8yEZY7HqERQ21bcaou7PIzxF6IHRXMf7jVEkRKp9MzEATIv41vyvv5-s8gOrxyWmJXKUhtYptmREP6o5YOMSyOQryC2eaNv0IM4_1ZdiR6AR3GNGMu7guDxETLT7tRVdVd-JO_Ea0zglJ4Eg_53Cx17BGh39e8XA==> . 


Mitt's RTB Platform


Both presidential campaigns doubled their RTB spend in Q3 compared to Q2. But if the election were purely decided on real-time bidding activity, Romney would win, Rubicon finds and Mediapost reports. "Romney dominated Obama by a margin of seven percentage points of total RTB political category spending. Obama's campaign actually trailed a U.S. government campaign on child abuse by nearly as much of a margin." More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Nh-eZbwMx_l7Mv2VYminkj7p3GOxyX1DLDztTrtj5P49BgEWPIyjYF8DmTiwjOBtWJMbYqz1TiOunKyEnWW43dSec4-qz0J1KVRmavCNU8Mfv25yAhlKvMdfMknJLBQ0Asls4j7Jb8yAerKlDfgxd9nZLaxQ3KEwQoTQhr5dNBxOWHf5kDxYSEeiZtEKpHvPJq4UDbsVW6dDSDI06Mc6uUnGDHIzBg5ybqS2A_mfcbQ=>

Facebook To Report


J.P. Morgan analyst Doug Anmuth has questions for Facebook ahead of the company's Q3 2012 earnings release later today <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rxJ9GP43uvynjZgCZhedKWS7l4Ah06zE4lCxKfxFj3iYB-AoB4uzDXNikisYCiQbUEILSs4muN2--gvz1i1z0Yh3VKK_4jQ_9FVP6D01Ysx0hQSrB4sCTFZWIU0z3ZAaAlDuaBva5kn62QLrAtIeLsT6otrBrTya> . Among his Qs: "Can Ad Revenue Re-Accelerate? What Will the Sponsored Stories and Mobile Run-Rate Be? How Will Web Marketplace Ad Revenue Fare in the Mobile Transition? Is Sponsored Stories Revenue Incremental? Are Sponsored Stories Weighing on the User Experience? How Big Is the Facebook AdExchange...How Big Can It Be?" So many questions, so little time. 


Compete Slapped


TNS-owned Compete has settled with the FTC over charges it didn't sufficiently disclose its data collection -- and then failed to protect the data it did collect. "The proposed settlement will require that Compete obtain consumers' express consent before collecting any data from Compete software downloaded onto consumers' computers, that the company delete or anonymize the use of the consumer data it already has collected, and that it provide directions to consumers for uninstalling its software." Earlier this year the agency settled with Upromise, which licensed Compete software. Read more.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rxJ9GP43uvxCQlwDFiu41NhfidRFfeg4oNocnZy9QIBV-nCPxgGo7e1Tmc2Pvt5g2bX2gRxbgwJf9Aw1QQD-pm8YbuW9l9iSQWHCKcpEAMB4yzPmNSb14a3vDfMQnEPPnkWEZlXempzFElZncS6L_A==> 


Ancestry Acquired


PE Firm Pemira has agreed to acquire genealogical info site Ancestry.com in a deal valued at $1.6 billion, Bloomberg's Aaron Kirchfeld and Mark Milian report. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rxJ9GP43uvwZsqmfSAYONkN1R5gMFJvXOJ0793pefCBykfy6GCsg9Y6StUtim_azW4DKTtethgqs7UFcZ0NJ9WD-N3zEMzU7MDpx8ojzlqm9GZtm-bEhDfKnmsSPmm_-LjlNP1Yu6Q7xCx5hxSVbGpn45mS1br0A0D1G1TJ8LtIA_cODo0vsNzF7IOb1wy2WrNJaSyzDjmrsI6hHVbsbDVmCaisZmTwV> . The company stumbled when it tried to produce a TV show that failed. But in the end, it's online data make it an attractive asset, especially considering that it just passed the 2 million user mark. "The business model lends itself to being privately owned," said BMO Capital Markets analyst Edward Williams. "They have a very strong cash flow -- a very predictable cash-flow business -- and I think that the reason to go private, generally, is that the public market is not valuing you appropriately." For more background, read this data-driven, AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rxJ9GP43uvyc85NhaqLARIZztW8uPLEMYmdM_tsOA4Dhr6sX829L1PSel3gX1zrlb3WpV_H3snS_xRvG1rPgAZA-wYOJQRaQvgQzeYrqLRi2gwKLw8lkVKvuPPtem2RW5liavk1cvWC8L1h0P7oYBFjgWvC8eCYn> &A with Ancestry EVP & GM Josh Hanna from May 2011. 


Past Behavioral Targeting


Behavioral targeting OwnerIQ says it will generate $30 million in revenue this year and is "on a growth trajectory that puts us at a $100 million company in a couple years," CEO and co-founder Jay Habegger told Boston Business Journal's Kyle Alspach. Habegger points to targeting that's based on what audience members already own to develop profiles of what they might be interested in when it comes to online ads. At the same time, he vows that all user data is anonymous. "When we get that ID, we then look into our database to say, 'Do we know anything about ID 1234?'" he said. "And if we do know something about ID 1234, we make a decision on whether we want to buy this ad spot or not." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rxJ9GP43uvx5ptvAhMr-0g5OHcXj5tUsNl3a3X2JESopxLlkYGr1gFbAYbU3faf67FYc55SWcI5Y7s80SugqArXOUn-xz3ME9zChlcZppLJ7n5dq83a05umkeKBfIiV9wV5BqhTanPDlA-HsAjRU8J7dx7gDiBNPXviwqu52TQ6akbg5G8QD4KiI77kkSTJxxoAFDJ8a5-qgNronZboJjSPzz-3mzecLsxhogc2nkIg=> . 


Declining CPCs


Facebook marketing agency TBG Digital published its Q3 analysis of Facebook ads yesterday. InsideFacebook's Brittany Darwell analyzes the data as "mobile and desktop News Feed ads have driven down costs per click to averages not seen since 2010." She adds, "When more users click on ads, Facebook can earn its target CPM while advertisers spend less per click." Is there a connection between declining Google CPC's and declining Facebook CPC's? There's more inventory than ever - everywhere! Read the article <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rxJ9GP43uvwdcgNKIRSUsadmR4S8tumLYHSRru9Ak_8uKlWotNkAGFpNj3EIr5su2nA7FTHhQrxMRg1fXKLujL5i0oNflJXz0QyFQTCt-cBBMhV8dim7PvT6H8oB3IWMDJDpE2Roj3bh7VYvte6phBjhdkILOKwbq8F7atnEbLQnHLxzgSOaaC9_L9jDp9ohlNpK1LwHHOfkgv8WuIJjeUYe2wbQJCgICAR8h6wpd_9PWPj84hmH9WWgI5ED8MU7> . And, see the report. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rxJ9GP43uvyahCOqU8FjiMNPVQd8rv_7EcUUi9pnKmu3GQa_Hbu8QmVp_5IEbXp7Js7X0OBnCCt152eUW8STvPR6WaympSwC-phUbfep-LNQGsnvtiUh9Q6kFbucFTPp64Fb5NOItd-uLDNkuLOydMcuQtFwxYNP22ZbEUyFv6o=>

App Glass Half-Full


Mobile analytics provider Flurry has some good news and some challenging news for app makers. Results of a study of 230k apps and their usage shows that app makers are getting better at holding a consumer's attention longer. At the same time, usage rates are lower "because consumers have more choice than ever and are splitting their time across more applications," Flurry rep Peter Farrago writes in a blog post. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rxJ9GP43uvz0TDdOM3Zb2X9MKG7JsuWvcPh0S_qqNE_AWHMIDz3eWhLlPj2-6gHuLDtqSwRNVxWywuPJhR3Lh1xC_Qor7TGpptj7lUc9G_aLv5UiXSkDwuU9sFseJzkw0ec2RKsQ9WmUz9KZOdpxe3Bz0l-ydDxJ59P5g72JrmsSRCDo-UQ-eA==> . 


Human Power


Writing for ClickZ, Larry Allen takes exception to dream of automation. He writes, "There is still a lot of education needed. And the best way to make that happen is to put a seller in front of a client...We still have the marketer and the traditional media agency, but we also have the trading desks and demand-side platforms (DSPs). These folks need to be educated too." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rxJ9GP43uvxtVe3Ie3UuJH12svJhPzSy08i5zE5ni12buraEEmyyTsMz40R2HPaZ3oSNJxHZuy63VdobGU7tq6SYAjCWDsNOoFfJNSfUGxDg2NqngoG-JLm3PLCMT4XjwzqFZh9BMItv9dYh0QEh9H4hZjRc6JRMx_vlrKhcy8Qsy9uAX3p4H2HDt_bzPQrp7eNvgzt04tw=>

Yahoo! Returns To Tech


Have time for today's Yahoo! earnings call at 5p ET today <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD6rCjfROyC5FsRbIhPYI7rjh8C-di49QFv99OHaQFk1GR_sTOl-GTM43e19aoQ5IeJGsiIRb8ESqXHFtvkvTiQMQTuW0c5h_CU7hwURMI_UYNHYIn1ijd_R> ? If you're an ad technology aficionado, you may want to tune in. Reuters says that Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer will declare that her company is back to being tech-focused. The "PubMatic, Turn and Millennial Media" acquisition rumors make it into the article as the Reuters reporters elaborate, "The new strategy is not without risks: it positions Yahoo squarely against Facebook Inc and Google. It also risks alienating a large, media-focused contingent that is already weakened by the departure of Ross Levinsohn, who had championed a media-centric approach when he was interim CEO before Mayer's arrival in July." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD58ZdMI8GexsgmbxorGOvKVHHW1MmDdnAWuuGH4RdRBiHgT2dVd0b6RSnSsvMwWUZlQwVZpkCHgmYiTQutzhdwqlaH2PXaDawUsSojMHqENk4DXRMccCpVpR7TFGZ2KHCxbwb0-SJrQ8LJMWH_OzQ-Sg5iiOz7xRb96iexZzk2nxkBn4QZ-rl5wb2xWXlwLp9Q=>  


Ad Hijacker Strikes Again


For more than a year, Sambreel Holdings has been placing billions of unauthorized ads on websites like AOL, the BBC and the New York Times. And it's not stopping, reports paidContent's Jeff Roberts, primarily because ad exchanges are turning a blind eye to the problem. "The allegations that Sambreel uses trickery to invade users' computers is backed by Ben Edelman, a computer expert at Harvard Business School," Roberts writes. "Edelman says the adware is coming in through various bundles, including 'trinkets' like the programs that promises to let you see 'who has viewed you on Facebook.' The end result is the same - the user gets a junky product and adware that makes the computer run slower." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD7d5Ff0CphmIWIYF6QemaYkiLxmjOkG5VLqoog6ORXt6VjWQBCQxrAHS3FPkHkWc5901YcqtMSCi6M5QrXXPZkxw7HkhWbi7m1EwOswn9FoQ6vueVU7DOMW-TXUtD3v-V7DYZ2ySvCBpeSl1p_cbVQxfNXIka2E9P_7zmHAz21wWGh7m5B0TlcfNJJewCY9GnxoLlZ3pTb-fQ==>  


Microsoft Offloading Atlas


Microsoft is considering selling Atlas to AppNexus. According to AdAge's Jason Del Rey, Mediaocean and Adobe are also entertaining possible overtures by Microsoft to sell the ad serving unit, which it originally bought as part of the $6.2 billion aQuantive acquisition in 2007. The first time word of an AppNexus/Atlas hand-off was mentioned, AppNexus CEO Brian O'Kelley told AdAge, "Microsoft either has to invest heavily in Atlas to get rid of those disgruntled customers or I think they do need to find a happy home for it." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD5JupaJeBG3C3Fugzko4ngI8E1yEYI4RuAltINHBfCuIPO0cA2YU0PZPSEdOT8oKQjo-J6qDoIWvFHaPIHyKjqHMpKWefrAKH6--KSMwlKNiuqB-c_-bCUSKb8xASB0ouG0f9XCmFA_-qknwaq_K0w2nHU3y5p1czPGbQvQNzgWQscIfMazNhdPsF23t658SWSmH_6gLNmuO3YrBLG1oD_b> . In a June AdExchanger interview <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD6FNvPxSLcioW6q-otXdA3xmDodwv60bDZ6DcShMK4IAyyCkkEP9jXAlXiNJgKUF_nnaZDNBTYLu9Pb_5BqY8mSuYIziEvIdzEENThBoad7xcEwUxZ9PlFtqud0VgewC1e5cpG5HkT1QkxfDR7ZaUD5BvCOyPOUqAlKF7Sr4dYp0Q==> , Microsoft's Rik van der Kooi sounded inclined to hold onto Atlas: "The right home for Atlas is us continuing to develop on the Atlas stack." 


Facebook Display


In Rome, at the Internatinal Conference of Online Media Measurement <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD61SxYw--l_Oqh-EfQz3NXzRIuo7fIsvxzWWVRT7huyyKcA9An9iWaGAxGjtwrxEEbKkzoUlv67fHx5hDff3FdXAiWeCr3Hix-srOubPORzTmBmmi5ZaW5V9MD6DyTOjfU=>  conference - i-com, for short -, Adweek's Chris Heine reports that brands believe in Facebook ads. Kellogg's Director of Insights and Analytics Aaron Fetters said, "There's no doubt from my perspective that Facebook ads and other display ads drive [sales] volume". Facebook's Brad Smallwood spoke up for the display crowd, too, saying that "trust in display as a branding tool is going in the right direction as advertisers evolve how they think about digital," according to Heine. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD4AbMnpmSb84Q7q1GQpDo-0C_nnmYCssMCk3I8CLc63BilomqmEZ9zDgLwiDIk3GQLeWP_f5atT1v4CyDdXhgwxwbFZgGx7g0wSqfmTJJks0H4_9fwUJAHMmKPcWFBMw617qBsL1SvgTIvXkxTTtUoHwOVXbiqq65wf53Ov6Ynv-kbX5Q4hwyRVD6Ej8_G_ljVy341mROb_ow==> . A key takeaway: native ads are display ads. 


Visualization Is Not Knowledge


Data visualization, with its attractive graphs - well, relatively attractive when compared to spreadsheets - has represented the sweet coating on an otherwise bitter pill. "Graphs do not translate data into knowledge, rather, they help you take one step toward it," writes Harmelin Media analyst Aaron Reinitz in Mediapost, suggesting that "radical change" is needed in the form of greater use of artificial intelligence and acknowledgement of the limits of current data collection methods. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD5K6mwTWCffzMzSOtAEWgKOMdBI_Gk2_rIe7KZCtvvg3-DszNQN8vVhVvPV8W82y2bSsHDGWowoSidKvwKEXNNau-g7xpJ62Um_e0gBeL35_oCwSOYmzQs6NkE-lblUOc-VUMwDtx58zpa4FWh9WKg1t1-jvm3R7s8nz_r9s8hdklsYfXnG4xIObCFqQi0xqBde_7TgEce7PgnBaQ0VnU_a> .

Microsoft's Data


Even as it takes guff from industry for giving away the data farm on Do-Not-Track, Microsoft is modifying its own privacy policies to allow greater use of user data across its services. Edward Wyatt and Nick Wingfield note the similarities to a Google policy shift earlier this year. "Google's expanded powers drew scathing criticism from privacy advocates, probing inquiries from regulators and broadside attacks from rivals. Those included Microsoft, which bought full-page newspaper ads telling Google users that Google did not care about their privacy, an accusation it quickly denied." Read more.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD7dguOPgUHk-3i5QM3wdo9FhKQ1V4jewY1lo5zP8cNwoeOcfbQJab3jBgofhy_bBzOKXNLPJCPC7xrrOyZIFfoLZh3b9Na5CaQBRjGmog-XFK_mHLHmG4HDLVg-HkONilT3N29oZWXETjrYthdXHU0GiSFb0kQ5RxhqlUzauLG1Zp48vhmBRrY0P5eDu6ARufqIo12gNBQzhG2Nt9qBTLVM7aCXxNZyoo4xIYZvcOB0SQ==> 


Forget the Uber Cookie


Adchemy CEO Murthy Nukala gazes into his crystal ball and sees our device future broken into a million little pieces. "Without an über-cookie, it seems like the online advertising market is set to become highly fragmented by device moving forward...Greater fragmentation means greater advertiser inefficiency, which means online advertiser spend doesn't reach its full potential." The solution he argues is to embrace a new "unit of trade" in the form of intent. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD7jYRvaeq-x9PRb01J-Xy1HU0020gbhhKPTmnfVid84JN4xpph8gLB5v2eld52MuC8jmtcy1FOVhudvG85od__ArrNq2oeINW9Xy1gnEkSzO-SEsavtpMkJ2osVdoFEZQxVLVnH_VmPVQ==>  And, if you need more, you may want to try this press release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD4n--uxeGvKyQTF-kviq4KPI20LH8nvhfLXyu5oXARozocbTnh88QuzJaLLiUqu0eoiMSj9vZwILNObRAlZx6yVGY45_BDOKBfZfjakmzMrTcMFfvh4BroUG6B5ylhEfs8QtpOUVGlxU7_L1AZL7x8X2jDJJJoNzvZoKDk9lxhQkC7cKZwWQByjg60PHFMf9faJW9XAWVLx0VBZHMpFRhGLscuCi3RDBugQVQmVYlVwauFfzQqI5HU-yo3_KR-NzUk=>  announcing Adchemy's deployment of "intent maps" through Bing advertisers (Microsoft - Bing's owner - is an Adchemy investor). 


Targeting Ads


Demandbase <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD5z3UySJtirGxr74peEd-MOOTPm9xr6D6qfPTQ6g9BO8ijVXnr-68FxcdQ18awKY5yAgyMnVFc4Ovw-D7ukg2yMyBbgGb1jXP0d2jz9_EFbbQ==> , which has been optimizing websites for marketers, is getting into the ad platform business with its new Company Targeted Advertising platform which leverages ad exchange inventory. Destination CRM explains how it works: Demandbase "identifies visitors who go to the customer's Web site to determine if they qualify to receive the customer's ad. Built on the backbone of the Demandbase Real Time ID Service, the Targeted Advertising platform matches information about a Web site visitor's company, such as company name, industry, size, geographic location, number of employees, and revenue, with more than 1.5 billion corporate IP addresses in real time, without the use of cookies." It's about the IP. Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD7vnUytSjIZQgdmgjK8RHTSZpt0NJg7v78cWmdKH6rDXUgdE_D1bQkfA-MeR-wwzSKnlJx2LqyTvelgVQYx74zkYfJFlQQoZ8mb7pjVfRNf01m2Sd6tBStPbkmU29XLB4US4zDdsDQpf-aTmCoG9HKcSDXZYfz2XcoIlIgoGIaZLfyyKPfxcZ99YrKSy7fMN0rZwmzGoVrPbXSaBj_07E0w_zXVN7Njh2K9bCMCrP9ylobmJx55rhlCGmcjjsNz9r-B8Fd99FanvQ==>  


Human-Centered Loyalty


Taking apart existing loyalty models favored by today's marketing, digital strategist Ana Andjelic sees decision-making, business design, and experience design as the "three pillars" for re-building loyalty. She says in Fast Company that the new models will "replace a rigid points system with one that's flexible and adaptive to current customer requirements and competitive market offerings. They are so simple that they don't require a learning curve. They are built upon already existing customer behaviors. They account for consumers' preference for many small gains, and offer them frequent incremental rewards instead of big infrequent ones." Make it more human. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001g1oMVl1iUD4s2qpoWY6nRUcIV47o4agfjWkjjWiQvbMoO1JBJPT5wG0v1UAxHmZFGkRfmzsAZHNmUE53qHhgVMiE8w8yfI5H3g6kZzNnjf0ngrauTin4ha8sKUxbhVUKlj_aQZKgYwsRJkpiO3B-V92X_P70hyCuu1wjRWJeaag-v65omgaRtuVOAQm9vxhQ> .

Traffic acquisition costs claimed 26 percent of the ad dollars Google shares with its network partners, up slightly from last year's 24 percent..."(visit AdExchanger)
*	Placecast Brings Mobile and Local Knowledge to Card-Linked Offers Space <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0W2Cgc_HZ-PzEM2G_1IcBMzWBGMzCSsYkoOaCq7H4Xf2hCzoI7lqb7Qpa2mB7LPDeDY93v8X2fcglHpgr5zdlaUuunmMTmVGozVhwDZCVUu2E8mTajU3fMhBLEaU7GRTQkOXylbVPwTZ-ITFYaGD-IviS3jglXfF3OP5vFPEeXvU5QhQpXHQ67qhqdibH-jiG6EHpvFtBkOCJDkY7ATZlxIzGcsUi2k0VE=>  "In the case of Placecast, users opt in to receive deal alerts through a relationship with their wireless carrier, credit card issuer or retailer. Paparo Departs AppNexus


What's up with AppNexus? Business Insider's Nicholas Carlson offers one answer, describing a mixed bag of recent events at the company, the freshest of which is the exit of product guy Ari Paparo. AppNexus continues to grow, with a headcount numbering 350 globally, but has been challenged on funding and exec retention, according to Carlson. There are also rumors about the company's efforts to raise late stage funding at a high valuation, possibly as high as $800,000 (or, we hear, higher). Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0X0xlLpM6l3z1NLRRzaKXisWjpONgdaML2GUDV1DCy9w3o_LTD-OvU32e2ZGxGVI2O08s2t_SK-cCNVuWBCk1Wb0DDUECPZ_ujGDTIVJI44N9lk9U9w9nw0qX1_uFP1dXduA418XSj5rRoUfZ-xcxzu8Yl8u72yJjRSkyQ4OYBtN24yWaQfRcxTHBSuPhXhdsM=>  Paparo tweeted this morning <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0W_W5jfgjxQ9wN_XnPluhxvrneqbxqm3ioJIXkZA9I59fvZ9PrHSBw4KOT06rG_ZYE6d7JiYOyDwVsgX8ohxmEmP5GgFpPAzugR_e7r6cVwj-XB7TdTGe3sS6ViQfhaCxgjEVgLdW9Eu6scvB3gO-kj> , "AppNexus is the coolest company in ad tech and in I wish the best for @bokelley <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0U3sExXtsgY3EQ06HDkPzsP7-5dzzkZb__A2r4VWCvxcaMWUNjNpOZqNlzWacKC2S4Hf10OmuojXpZ-4p07wUzR1SSgcwv5_2okCnfJJqFw1g==> , @mrubenstein99 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0V1FqF1z114PBFxZXNQ1daxYiXW9iws2NYI2IeSJI30e7m_jNsspbi_Lso8sgJIhh251hgTlu0iVTI6Yr6tMHkp-s7cV5z6LCyihYuS6qzJE9ayzmj93ICL>  and the team!" 


IBM's Future


IBM reported its results on Tuesday and "only" met Wall Street expectations by earning $3.8 billion. Marketwatch covers the news and quotes a Wall Street analyst, "'IBM's results are a sign of a challenging demand environment,' said Janney Capital Markets analyst Joseph Foresi, who cut his rating on the stock to neutral from buy. 'We believe the IT-demand environment remains stable, which doesn't imply growth.'" Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0UaZCdhByIDRGqsOhmW1Uk1KF3kAwEEncqFbDbrCuwE8GpvPlVXPotAWSK6jAUpVWUxN4_dYXBytSxV0BPBIvJpeM4hqA33lOe-pz8Z7MADJDSVGzp42v4VEwQbuQHi056mn2cP-MMvClUavyBN3uDix6VbilIFFpTGygGcmmrmZC-pNp299GjMJmvGkXk-KSIYhbB5MKCuI0Zor2T7BI1yk-LLL8Gq0hwQIeori8J26oVFbBPw-nKj8cQu85SExPw=> . And that's why serving the CMO is interesting to IBM - plenty of efficiency to create and money to make. 


Jumptap At The Crossroads


Mobile ad network Jumptap has an interesting dilemma: does it sell itself to a larger company or does it go the IPO route? As Jumptap CEO George Bell tells Reuters' Sayantani Ghosh "It's a potential path for the company for sure. We are very pleased with the way the industry has responded to Millennial's stock; that's a good thing for us." Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0UZNnes0L5Yu5oMxUoWawl_NHkdEI2EvIXIOA7qbceM1EX7jhJb1zJLRU-tL0Ah96jT5yjx9ruy0yxnvn_451-oIPxjBOOEL1gAWC3wOBwYRwSdtaYNOnK7YKuC39vvoe8HXE5TsD7nMThv5-HePa3ojyjbDgAXfnhk570OB92TYNAFY5rgvYMAssxTy2jF8ajfm9-QEZPVKs4ttX0qspZzTCXIOysTtw0AZZ-gRWgMWJ47Vab_uiY42M8_zhBtGm-SJVi9ubufbA==> . 


No More Home Pages


On Digiday, Josh Sternberg corrals opinion on "Premium in the Post-Homepage Era.' Demand Media's svp of sales and marketing, Erika Nardini, tells Sternberg, "The idea of building a publishing company and media destination built on millions of side doors is the future." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0VvP0J-ZQHGtyiyfJSP85mXM8CYm1FB4Wsw45alf3-Rwc-N51Pz50U_vrdmPtSPoPuYwFozDjEhv8aIYA4qfnXdhzIL6KMOlWl8ca2x0bmVaPGyUWQJiQLchq7wMvPOckdns0IhyI8ptRgV4_pDZeFroWv2YUXsc58K0Ar8sFOyaQ==>  


Discovering Ads


Forbes says retail site Fab it's spending $25 million in Facebook ads this year. CEO Jason Goldberg is adamant on his company's "digital ads" preference according to Forbes. "Facebook ads are more effective than Google search or display ads, because Google ads are based on intent, while Fab is designed for people to discover new items they aren't searching for. Fab is designed to be a site people sign up for and browse around and eventually make purchases, Goldberg says." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0W930YhD-v7-TGIPdf--gOt-ua7W_5DNkRetyAV1LMlZOY4XmWW6IZ79gRDDTgTh5_kae-R-F2mBJf2Wx-yvmoFl1HIK7z87pZBy6Y1V1U8qI3Q0GC_te3ywJYXA_DkHs8SEK5ZkBbrhJvVqjM_v48y1cQKUZXDuem0AawU-lpqYLz808oQP6EcMgkN7BOWrt6wxbgOCr7ymgxA4RrQejHDoluKGqnILdeQWKj-Rr1LypQ2atrNlj_I>

Facebook's Roman Roadshow

 
At a the I-Com Global Summit in Italy this week, marketers from Kellogg's and Starwood Hotels & Resorts threw votes of confidence behind Facebook advertising. As reported by AdWeek's Chris Heine, Starwood's Janice Chan told the crowd "Facebook ads have driven room bookings in Asia in her recent tests. The hospitality brand will now likely invest more on the platform in Europe and the Americas, she said." Insights guru Brad Smallwood was on the scene preaching the company's "view through" gospel. Read more.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0X-PiI2AxeZhxZqXDT3dlkQvVaeZ8e7pqE6z9jOPoXoB9rqPcw9PWwnZsLn2jA5ZGGU2k0cpafNlgs3UYe9ZSTpCRiuEAz-5INfN9MlD0jJtKsfrFPeGECFQFNInV3smar3nAnvRwi9r2o-EFJQiyWogn9i9tQ_3ToRm8_gorE_NpbyCyE88-MxPLiQBCEYJ2eiVz9rqn18bw==> 


Lerer Ventures Funds Namely


Cloud-based HR Systems company Namely has raised $750,000 in funding from seed stage investors Lerer Ventures. CEO Matt Straz says in a Q&A on The Makegood, "Namely will become even more capable in the months to come and we will be developing new tools to further measure the performance of teams and people," he said. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0VocFjjKbkYDiL6yrId0UUuNYq4GrvWwpM2by-fShBoI7wvxW-ZdkROmpjrhYGanBCUscvHEqEHcRmQJ2-Zih2XwL5aYFBJDJvqiN-dqmgIOPqXeMXhdnDn4PhgEIwE3u36k0JcJ52qZP7uLheDQWqSXBxaStYVqTu95Sb87otbXWoLy39vY1nO> . 


Another Look At 'Viewability'


"Viewability" is hot data point these days, offering brand marketers the promise of digital consumer engagement similar to traditional media. But it's far from perfect as a metric, and it can actually create new problems, says Phillipp Pieper, founder and CEO of Proximic, writing in AdAge. "Viewability fails where it counts a view (an ad that loads on a viewed page for more than certain number of seconds), but ignores other signals (pictures, ads, page quality) competing for the user's attention that, taken together, may distract the user from viewing the ad message." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001p_jwpxp2y0Vr9csqNwlvZ6wek01H4VyXOiQTPVaSn15Nu5d3is6cdQs4UBocKfPST5stR04RfGo5U2ULSy8lUSbuFdeuMl6hjktb_YFKl4YvJrv0nOs58UYhjy0DO3xdZB5GbOcRnYoqf6uXEi6NzmgH0YoZcgDnXuxkEs8WFn2Wo_R1Zl-hwMSSugSL03XMEpjOKEcmAGo=> .

AdSense Alternatives


Google has long banked on small- to medium-sized businesses to boost revenues through AdWords and AdSense offerings. But the search giant can no longer take those dollars for granted, as the NYT's Darren Dahl reports that small businesses are looking for alternatives. "Most of our paid efforts shifted to platforms like LinkedIn, where we could target for the right kinds of job titles in line with our target customer profiles," said Dan Slagen, who is in charge of advertising at HubSpot, which helps set up blog programs for small companies. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rC_As_sK0dFSHjk5WcjIpZCfk_x2PTJ8fZkm7t7LX5l4uUL5_LnDTVwXgTFxu8HaJLhJC4qeLwJCfbciWiE_snKNGZ-r9yn_gxNVVAOvObFsuvFJSwsfPTDemdP9jjBnNEcIU5qUrd8UqK2o9QioZ-d9e7vUdUaC2DHr1h64ZdM6ySnQ_k-tnPHTUdgZhvSVwtjSj2NOGvMYMiJxNH95cJ41zJVTYBSyY_AJzyOhc3dfvtNuL-gotuDzo1ZEHWvTmBd7mu1WIhBI9p4OgJXHT97u9LHTkxdxsmcXjNaAj4ZDpskTf-_BDQ==> . 


Power to the Data Brokers


In an AdAge piece on the impact of Do-Not-Track, Evidon CEO Scott Evidon says if privacy advocates and Microsoft get their way, "Those transacting data online will continue to do so, and perhaps will get richer. This could go down as the mother of all unintended consequences." Read it.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rC_As_sK0dHPrwjYzqqJtZt8By1MnSoP3L7IlvF3PItVojD2JTRkEmlOYnishS6oEveofEjNMGRaeOd5LLAwnjcYiAv3BIwnkp8x4nIu3nOr2WoyuAR2q4GjSDFlF6uibDKCWnIa-oC9Qui4VXmQBmojRuuQvAYRxJCPC635rc-DFVocMpbNSw==> 


EMEA Powers Up


First-half 2012 saw digital ads explode in the MIddle East & Africa (+30.3% spending growth) and Europe wasn't too shabby either, according to Nielsen's global AdView Pulse report. "Interestingly, despite being down in overall ad spend, Europe saw the third highest increase in Internet ad spend of any region (+11.2%)." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rC_As_sK0dFKGoV1_v5jUp--2hkltvOg1t7_j_PyAjo4GzEQ3Tbqd_vEQpUXMEg7sVLWfEEURGlhH7UgM4JExNmNB-IcZAq8N343bTS43-7ZrmBw4dmRBtzTUJALPoCpvbTXTwwr9WA=>  


Greene 'Likes' Vendor


Data-driven, digital ad research guru, Michael Greene, has left Forrester Research and joined AudienceScience as its Director of Research. From the release, "He will be working with sales and strategic accounts to provide world-class thought leadership, training and support to enterprise clients. This includes research, reporting, and training programs." Goals for the AudienceScience sales team just increased. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rC_As_sK0dGw0LtGwKxSofOJHxDYHJPQ85y03Oa2R2JpvY62AQre680D888Pk63lfsO4w5pxHDDhunGvVsL-TWUFifRLdzt54WHIRpSidbXipdO7ZlybCo_43SVtTweqqWPgQXzTd0OLQDWZ_TQ6jfigjSQ6rlU6d9s1_7rEjMqDGakK9hmYXUve49UsPxST_t_pBGXvSEluOWyLydMdrhsIbynARpBt3oZXriTObM7LuMjK8pFvB_lrg5Uhp2d9> . Greene reports into former Forrester Research-er Emily Riley who is AudienceScience's VP Marketing and Sales Strategy. 


Creative Ad Tech


In a ClickZ piece on display advertising's so-called "awkward stage," Aubrey Beck of agency SteelHouse writes, "We spend so much time and money coordinating, planning, and executing thoughtful and engaging creative collateral across all other marketing channels - eye-catching print campaigns, hypnotizing television spots, interactive live social events - but now it's time for online ads to perform along with their fellow comrades in the well-oiled interconnected brand marketing landscape." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rC_As_sK0dFDdwl51PVb2Rb3JAyb5n1k_M4im_85czFP1pbYXoymRHPfHuU11_ctQS0EIWLBb0fDPjJATJkt1OGcImGoBG38HUOSpV4EWaChScgfNqzGd6nXyoxlLXorcgrXv5v4BaOBLxbOATzSxhgItzJmozVd52hVHCDZlO2m8YQBoPIeHsWPdg37x5jamDiXn3UcP9Sdq8vWQ-lCytik7sRgQZWzt3myS59PxBxUBnydxEIWH7OxkOSqRzpi>

HTML5 And Apple


Specific Media's Myspace investor partner, Justin Timberlake, has scored venture capital gold. CNET reports that an HTML5 and web app creative agency - "Particle" - in which Timberlake was invested has been acquired by Apple. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rC_As_sK0dEacBDwPWjECkfqANY3XgXPxg_wcWFowQWMABV8n-ufz9RxzmgGTFQE-iLXWRdOJU-fGgD8Gdm_nByr6_-26j0MOB9LPa67jzdB0ETDl1AvbZJEPSAyppqPDu0HFl1dZD5mFhlGTpOhymoNAGX4g2mMTmuP3PFJ8exD2g-Hbs3xMx9cK-odi2hPLb4gRT5Ro0Zu-wYmn6I3ysHLtmUdrf9U>  CNET writes, "Several of Particle's employees previously worked with Yahoo as part of its user experience design group. Founder and Chief Technology Officer Aubrey Anderson also consulted for Apple between 2006 and 2008, according to his LinkedIn profile <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rC_As_sK0dFEEd0N5hlu6ox8rUjEmYFXfthtkIXckuKYWZvGN4lpPnhl7QC7Cu2pfQdZ8PbQydZx3y5pwF8EeZwN3p_Ly1tAG_tV4ngIcZ30iECP9oigew==> ." 


Charge It!


After a false start last year, MasterCard has started to analyze transaction data and is selling it to marketers looking to support direct targeted ads, the FT's Emily Steel reports. Read it (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rC_As_sK0dHLCnHnumFpo79aD9lh27lnx8kX5lPQktWchmF8O7NiT-qwJ_aU7vgq4GnxUVZzlTlTurxcsSJIYhdYiQgpHm1i2C2abOPggy_WgGnE-BSs97sNPpNwI7AcdHgjjLNIgA4vd6ug8RSuvuyiupXZ_7tvpQKyU90ekgosi-X7PEem4B8nraPdIZ0V> . The credit card company is launching a program designed to help generate revenue from its copious database of consumer purchases. The foundation of all of our solutions is transaction data," Susan Grossman, MasterCard's senior vice-president of media solutions, said during the pitch that has been viewed by the FT. 


Programming The Partner


Tag manager TagMan has started a partner program called "Stream" to help grow its business and that of its partners. The press release explains, "Once partners are certified on STREAM they gain instant access to TagMan's newly launched 'Drag-&-Tag' library..." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rC_As_sK0dFWj7A6Vad_eO6Vt33oLOOT5xY7tNU5kXKFG6IaiXxIjB7C6pPQFaaQlfNKX4ql2DJe2BldwwqzteGlzwOjjb7lXFXRAyAh52dXOzBsyZJMZERoaUXyayOgEEDT4elrrK20a4jmxyuNg5xxT7JIMeXXg36bH48_-fI=> . Turn, MediaMath, AppNexus, x+1 and others have previously started various flavors of partner programs to make their solutions sticky in the ad tech ecosystem.

*	New Challenge for Marketers: Preventing Non-Viewable Ads From Getting Credit <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6lSp3F5hVVvKOhv0KpH8_Yui-wLUF64Ai1llW58zZUPxWhmCW3zVtUuL0Bqb-EfZT1ek_6DGl_VEy76_OU3bPAjIO6raVKHwBsLR011Mg_4DYppbSpe_YPCdg32t-9XV7rAsNz3qZNNd27hXcDURdJLlZ8t0oxhJLkPqd40ytnbINfiuILomdT04K_kpKIGB2sX4qLDO7Ka53ua8g6TAEnfaUAo15rETWg=>  "'Just because brands and agencies might not pay for an unviewed impression doesn't mean that cookies won't be set, and when cookies are set, display ads not actually displayed will receive credit. Thus, expect that the post-viewability world will focus on a new question: how do we ignore unviewable impressions and assign credit only to viewable impressions?'..."(visit AdExchanger)
*	Most Online Ad Spending Is 'Guaranteed,' But Efficiency Tools Still Too Tilted Toward Remnant <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6mcx7RZFcTbExOAjRF2K3mxg08Tiv_p0yf43jSHL9G_KcBA-AV68-NsFbu1yJSIBYVuKhV4rdFtVcgHmRcPNvOt3uxqysML_isVj59HmL0OpFQQidxlIVzskxV7lHgvBVgTvnQA6Vt2rTajlpQhHVs36P-LN7GHcWyWKtlIWmxdsDh07k55dmJ3_Zu8cmGIWL3ND1XqxdkLA66Km081Mkm7KbZm00J7ortaMbp2oqL_5c8iZ4BnGrvgprDBYTED714=>  "Over the last five-plus years, the majority of the companies on Terry Kawaja's Lumascape have been building products and businesses to bring efficiencies to the remnant advertising market. But, 70 percent of online ad spend is in premium, guaranteed advertising. Isocket's platform brings the efficiency and automation available in the remnant market to the premium, guaranteed market..."(visit AdExchanger)
*	'Placed Panels' Look To Replace Demo Data With Location-Based 'Opt-Ins' <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6lB3gEF9gB650RwootLmxgTtq-XHx4OWcOIOSm1zQaefHT9K6UwR0wtrozu8EGpOJ0vNPVrEnr1AmLQ0pixf8vJYXl8oy3eD0J0nO3ui8XzBLim-DgndV-5Wb6G5b8CEeemXuOCLCvUvbJ-rVwBjORMLHNPH34lleWYSMyYxOr0eKafYw9kLupZOGHEPaNlyjcV-kViTqOtCxtr9JF18L1Q>  "'From a market research standpoint, we've found that people are more likely to participate in a location panel, when there is an incentive offered,' [David] Shim says.
