Barrett To Depart Yahoo


The news that Yahoo Chief Revenue Officer Michael Barrett would be leaving the company has been hinted at since Ross Levinsohn departed in July as acting CEO and head of North American sales. Although no official word about the exiting of Barrett, the former CEO of AdMeld, arrived by late afternoon, Ad Age's Jason Del Rey cited unidentified sources that Barrett's days at Yahoo were done following the hiring of CEO Marissa Mayer's erstwhile Google colleague, Henrique De Castro, as COO. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6nZFrL33d7_p5TPJj1UNL87jAsP0VrZBV-2tF4lonFMX8YM9lk3ZfX3DYulLpVIm3R9n9-KprmfaEQADiXPJBySg0ZaQ2foMAhEunxWDHzbGAV620-DQrpmLSsG2DVfqsO-7QMxOMBC7EXC1WvLcFZ5UWrYxbqNGiPEVjFY4Ik_XJk7eaojLtTLK5sSnpz3r9mzbiC-kj0qFQ==> . 


RTB Liquidity


In an opinion piece on AdMonsters, Digilant (née Adnetik) CEO Ed Montes delivers the data-driven Kool-aid but not before starting with some cold water, "..before my digital brethren rejoice or heap praise upon one another we should note that the RTB marketplace lacks the required liquidity for perfecting pricing and often lacks the requisite transparency." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6mG3hCg1eFuByJigUlOCKmAN5MeLdUDDPFDQhka3m0PKgOGT6NOcCSoRIIlyr3coLB9o6_OBaIHI5EVb0G7DZWxTwDG62mtWLfY8TqAq58iR77fISJF72LA5qYz2FlkeqhknEmBSVwB55nnqYkKxyVj> . 


Facebook Giveth


And Facebook taketh away, as InsideFacebook's Brittany Darwell reminds us in a piece on TBG Digital's ejection from the Preferred Marketing Developer Program. The company violated rules against talking about Facebook product tests. While it retains access to the Ads API it has been stripped of its badge. The intention is to get it back but, as Darwell writes, "It doesn't seem that Facebook has a formal process for re-entry into the PMD program, and neither company provided details about what TBG would need to do in order to regain its ads badge. We've heard of companies losing PMD status, but it's unclear whether any have rejoined." Read more.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6lxczCReX0uKPuLiIcyVpaTHpUUBYTIrueLokakt_8StQI_2HrvYd-W7RQbzqY2G9XY4qLsy1QGVShkfGsC3Kmj5qL6UNMMM9edmDhD9RgeOhYIERGDI-IxwdlsnSOjonE_D6vZ1CEICgjWWhvrTt7TxSwvaO1lXH9Z6m1X5juvR7kgtq17I4RmsAaaXKtbXHg=> 


Retargeting Freak Out


On Marketing Land, Danny Sullivan informs the masses about retargeting through Facebook Exchange and one of its customers, Walgreens. Walgreens didn't respond directly to Sullivan's queries, but he writes, "Currently, I no longer get either ad above, which were showing this morning. I also don't get ads for any new items I put into my basket. It could just be something that's unique to me, but I suspect Walgreens might have been a bit freaked out by my question and put retargeting on hold." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6kglkxPRUOFeielnlVOIyaGDQs9L_meU6tWS4FbqBpWwNeoXPtivF0N43BApjXff0DrLWzuJ8iwJHc2vSXDK0joRUZjjmXh89-ZF-Tk4KUxN-nfUkdZOuEmjCH83zJPGTVu1-5aNcolVg1KySPuVSDj_FOnhbv9xXs=>  


Don't Forget Display


In a new Forrester report, "The Purchase Path of Online Buyers in 2012," sponsored by GSI Commerce and its sister agency, True Action, Forrester analyst Sucharita Mulpuru derides last click attribution, "Because so many customers touched multiple marketing touchpoints prior to a transaction, it is critical that eBusiness professionals consider the full path to a completed transaction, particularly when tactics like display advertising or affiliate marketing are involved." Get the report (pay with some PII). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6lRy_IJZoeIgxxa8uPZF3M6zqOvfIU6Q7J-6JKEWeTyYuKKHxcpD3pcYPmFYT12x179OERrtzj0S4TL1P9eLUEnPHlEIKgAUs-Wmvbr8m-igDJJrgKfxwc22nzoGr8j9do=>

QR Code Tombstone


The Wall Street Journal reports on a new print technology that connects to online through the screen. Sounds simple from the WSJ's description of "touchscode" - "A user only needs to place the printed item on the screen of a tablet or smartphone-or place the screen on the item-and the invisible code immediately connects to the online content. No need to summon your device's camera and snap a shot of a bar code." Read more (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6l1LUojnGtUFuXhosMa8k-UO0Vi8ZoS2W3RzD-BNZ-sL-ccddIN672eU3KjIYIJ3cdq77A0OugMpPu-gCaUzggzlJF65heVUBV0xzbs693dgW6UjAwJBzhFQT1r5cPf_SG-jB2sc2hEJLkPjvAJ6sxY7ZhvbI27CyhKqja2rLrRyROeR3HA6qIt> . If it works, the loyalty card business will love this. Online/offline attribution may have found a new friend, too. 


Cross Platform R&F


Product releases from comScore and Nielsen are coming fast and furious as the companies race to master cross-platform audience measurement. ComScore's latest entry is a multi-platform version of its validated Campaign Essentials product -- launching in the U.S. today. It promises unduplicated audience validation across TV, web (display/video), and mobile (smartphones/tablets). Kate Sirkin, EVP global research director for Starcom MediaVest Group, says, "vCE MP is a welcome addition to the multi-platform marketplace because it addresses the need for demographics, reach/frequency, and GRPs within and across platforms." Press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6k8iVmLt0gL5llu26AfoPT2y0paF7S5svzfIHxVf29ig0xmPV7XeZGg_XX7Oo9tJTCliIHaK7FMx35Gtzjf7pZctpt2RwBXuydiU1WsnW-PeBhkZjfylUS6bGlsh97gP1S-wGzNrmdBAl9vcpoksDocPhlyUuZSEPxF45z7c8e5TuxnAuYvT1Hd0XspI6bmSs0iSiDU47bRRZarHoHg1Sxz8-l9MJs0mhQLxcg8TLoVROiZXpmO2yN3eZjMin1Du7fzfMsXNgtbVn82YHe8o-LG3cF9AdP49OKqizFbqKAAT3yG504GHArbuDBth6S0wa1gVUGCAvWKWN5QoMfW51ZeWCxtXtL8akU=>  


Live Video Limits


On his Streaming Media blog, Dan Rayburn analyzes live event video statistics of the jump from the "edge of space" by Felix Baumgartner. He notes that Akamai infrastructure was behind the streaming broadcast rather than Google's YouTube where most viewers were taking it in. "One thing that was clear from this webcast is that Google still can't seem to handle large-scale live events on their network." Is Akamai the Time Warner Cable of the future? Maybe they are already... and it would seem they are in a sweet spot for bringing together attribution-related data. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6k3UQBEQ0l6F7qRA262jLzIWjeSH0X0UhGBacsxw7r7tBzFRPmPEDEHfXZ4QtgUdygBZZB7xDAsd7vXUI8M1MU4sBbmNQay1g_loBc60fFKSaOVPsQ4UNb_6jQ5apmcZmhy4zjJ2PFaUt3_orjGftl9uQsGroAW1i0QG-SzCc5p3k3dmDVxIsTNdeWWchM3-9Swqr5eQZUSVEWwkSXdl7KHpKoH82bUQbI=>  Akamai is poking its head out a bit more on the retargeting front with a marketing budget, too. 


Expanding Video Ads


The Wall Street Journal Office Network, the Dow Jones company's out-of-home digital video business news property, has been working on improving the quality and effectiveness of its ad units. The WSJON, which operates in 760-plus office buildings, is adding IAB standard video ad units and is partnering with GfK MRI Doublebase on audience data and metrics to boost ad performance. "In addition to being preferred by our viewers, WSJON2.0 delivers increased advertising impact with stronger ad recall," says WSJON CEO Jim Harris. Read the release (PDF) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wHASpFSDd6mlcT1Z4EZaquWHlpjA4rApqnq-F4TiHvF8tJz8_bSfKh7igGW7uaYSK6FaMAPRL9lZ5wmbHGmGxDQZAR4h8dtiPpeFIv1-giTqvaBUxRpXCWFYcgk3bARRAgYXRsy5gXdTREOVXyJiqFTGGaLZd2p7eF7lHtx6bJc=> .

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email? Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo0ZSVweSl9c5_obEOb4GPvZSUGffmbeo3FzIUf1Ae8tZzW8mG7EEElBkicsPFLLdd1ulhe-TdbRxfKnfoV_TWFn9zIOT_ibwFPV5wXBxg7-uIGJl0sDiPQmfTW6zbjU5iI=> .

 

Tablet Ad Network


The shortcomings of mobile targeting continues to provide opportunities for the growth of ad networks. Mojiva announced yesterday that it has effectively re-branded the tablet audience of its ad network as another new ad network called Mojiva Tab <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo38VOby8azNZliMLwh9U1fL9yVFz_n7eLYsx1NQ2rnGBx7yA-wrXR0QR01fX8c0PtbjV9aLuZWXiCdtg34-OHThJKfxre283Nyy1CUPjQhfscDitpQtV-J3> . (Marketing, baby!) The company claims it's the first of its kind to target a growing, valuable audience. Drawing from 8,000 mobile publishers, the press release gives a sense of scale: "The number of tablet ad requests per month on the Mojiva ad network was 119 million in January 2011, increased to 655 million as of January 2012, and reached an impressive 2.13 billion tablet ad requests per month as of August 2012 - a nearly 20-fold increase in 20 months." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo0xE3BKAPgpLA6KjSqjY-yRgAiQlFk8W_9vqIr3lyUOR-WcH8eXYGeUp6RXc0IA03k2zvrjp3PF4Bfqb6Y3aOOZau8miHcXgC1f1Nii4W0WoL_z8TlTGJPipCu2Qx4M2AOZQSrM9T0WqBR24myu3GkkWtJbJRjWqnAc2qL07LaE2cQjI33yQ_J8LOickPqQW7m4agkqU7-4DnW6HyfrDzOaN7uNSG-Vcx7Jyf4Yh7zz5DBR7WY3YW2M> . 


Millennial's Q3


Millennial Media is forecasting a Q3 loss of between $1.9 and $2.4 million, but it says revenue grew faster at 85 percent year over year, versus just 76 percent last quarter. "We are delivering greater value to our advertising customers and developer partners through the use of technology and data which, in turn, is driving increased demand for our services and enhanced gross margin performance," says CEO Paul Palmieri. Prelim earnings release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo0gAGEv0CDkkPnUWb2dT5oOJij_HLXO_eb6y8FrPG0ZGKgzNDmcN0icPF9jHNvYqqlU6hCmq2OlOqXdFSylpEmguCAASJqBm4WWfNkIrlSCC59hFlOwtcHLBiys-OB1ppgmSmjtHeiWJWRw2PiznDiX2gUcFUQgHKtGP4-l8oDPIK-hp6-1mxzupHTx7N_Xagw-T6WH0uMXYLGvrW3af-u162WdQsOYbZE=>  Separately the mobile ad net is raising some money through a follow-on offering of a million new shares plus an extra nine million from existing stockholders. The cash is earmarked for "working capital and general corporate purposes." 


Attribution Platforms Hold Hands


VisualIQ and Korrelate announced that they would combine their attribution capabilities to provide a new online-offline attribution product through VisualIQ. According to the release, the new product calculates "the value of each marketing touchpoint experienced by each prospect across the entire marketing ecosystem with offline vehicle purchase data that quantifies the propensity for someone exposed to any of those touchpoints to buy a certain make and model of vehicle." Simple. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo0miAlDS7NBbL91S-_Egge8OFDrvajodM-o_FME_rnOtUuwSVXZjGaxKV8y-K7jqIKMkxHhyDD9hKEcD2ym4Z7sLteziB2GizLDYyE5eNWYwfpFK7kcKSncb1p7Js_I4RAXRysTXUu843AxzHq4E0O3yLqZr5v2l3yadwsavXObjZGc3bplHqaORWKt96yw2oEVTmwgNveBP4v9ucMLIbqdw3WledZf5r05aZ9sngx0m4Csl5036fKJCWrfWV-tpv1SZRJ_1OqFDA==>  


Data Mining's Rep


The DMA hopes a new consumer ad campaign will burnish the data industry's tarnished image. As reported by the New York Times Natasha Singer, the trade initiative goes by the highfalutin name "Data-Driven Marketing Institute" and aims to educate people on the benefits and the economic impact of the data mining industry. Read more.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo3FQueM9VqGV8ZnciY3S4fGcsbHAvyozSWrpOKCmxVDuNbh7_e1bzN1URNTei4WLtntoMB8Y-PJ-KXwoh2dTVR4_frbPpozEjWvII97eNrXKx_00e7JxaTDhtMjFKb6SMo7cDEFc0L7VtOmw7LdB3BQLpBILlJF-8Qt9UKIavF5pO29VYcwGPLFqCm6AP0AqF7uz2UGqmr6-yW7quxYNKjV2DUJ1F55Rvo=> 


Yielding To The Meter


Gannett Chief Digital Officer, David Payne, discusses his company's digital strategy on NetNewsCheck. In talking about his company's metered content yield, he says, "Revenue is up and actually well above what we expected for those properties. Any time you put a barrier to content, you're always going to be worried about that. Traffic is understandably down, but the users we have and the revenue we're able to generate from those users is higher. It's one of these balancing acts as you migrate away from everything being free all of the time." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo2jdtdOTF6TRWEjAbbmiF1mptYilWxk5QsmWvx4Sq3hqF-OwdB8Gtq19L3mOKnn8HQSrgdzA1LEgqlxQvMTsDcOIcWON3PFy3JtVC4Pu9ljnSXJl1o3eyNCM9Xwbj4owVnIQK3faOYZJIjyR2Zz6vVycWARlLPpAXgAbTdvchaXsWLTVgkBpIZT>  And, read the WSJ (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo1N1h3BvfCrL7S1i6BR7F32s0MF5XY8wvBmOfGt2gq3VCeYybh1Y26pGTSw4PiuSps_RSBYth8QNvNDOzbGIUbs5oY4lI43TrePBCfK1kONQ_hHSQBioxz1YzPtvSqzUHSCrqDPM0GqSvli6Qu2ilBAUxaOEUOHUGcvxhsF09O3BFpcQbPoIr6N> .

Buy-Side Private Marketplace


Buy-side platform [x+1] said yesterday that it has aggregated more than 40 publishers - including Forbes, trulia and The New York Times - into what it's calling a private marketplace. Mark Kopera explains on the [x+1] blog, "The [x+1] Private Marketplace gives advertisers at-scale access to new and premium inventory that is not available through open auction on exchanges or supply-side platforms (SSPs)." Also, it's another way for a programmatic buyer to get first look on inventory and audience that may end up making it to the exchanges eventually. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo0sVf3SftI7yXlhZNPO7PHEo02Vs74VyrIGjfDgN-S_8K0_OyBtrYfkzOooCUPrFDC4ZKbcIDJR_zLsmzxoCWbpf7sNy4qwIknwY4MqtyPVOPQHY0321Dgsh67TCYc2ycJNuOngBBLGIgKW1x-O5ZMF_drjc3qKYCGN4FNAP-GBSg==>  The publisher ad network evolves -or is it the exchange that is evolving? 


High Speed Trading


As the "trading desk" model propagates in digital advertising, Wall Street is re-thinking its high-speed trading. Scale has been an issue as The New York Times reports, "The challenges facing speed-focused firms are many, the biggest being the drop in trading volume on stock markets around the world in each of the last four years. This has made it harder to make profits for traders who quickly buy and sell shares offered by slower investors." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo1KZ3a1Po882_7Rdaceo4EfcSWCMXUWNFcN5gvPruvowZEuJRRx8KQlQ1xA06Nc1w-0uiW_1bw-GIS4_vNMf4Z9W9oypF2T3QUJ8MZkag8kSKIe_ZXp-5y1RZ4_Lc2a86Q0fkWk1S6AKAeXjxzwIEqSTRkaRt4TYDI1xY_GG62nQXbxkfekXdXQPJ3v9L6F0XY=> . The big difference here - in ads every impression is different; in stocks, many shares of stock are the same. 


Ad Tech Publisher


B2B data and ad targeting platform Bizo announced that it was adding to its product line with a site devoted to digital marketing news called "Digital Marketing Remix". Led by former B2B editor Sean Callahan, the news site will target marketers and be "a combination of original and aggregated content, focuses on digital marketing in all its forms, including online display advertising, data, email, mobile, search, social, data and analytic," according to the release. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo2HLS-Z08IG6lPAXlHDKC65VCpjMu0YGDp6ba47d0G6y-ZtsMxjkX4ZKu1fuz8aoayYaxkecXFdyNw4NqA5YAxh3N0oySrsMYm5W1o6rCBgsJyg4rc_OfpQN3JjJnMz-JziZLuoyUiwfgPJk6dAoQW0ZVwBBNvZxIeXUEmLqHej0XLD3iZ-72bd4fvOjs9Dwi-A_cfGGmZZ2476tyhNHygUKeehvAULo6FPRDMzieVPVmSGdH7AS7N9dLtKOD_Y1Vs=>  It could be a good source of B2B targeting data, too. See the site. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo0gAoWybBxuPxDn3ogjD-R3j7LRTycFmgr_UViv2p-_jJ8--KUlgcQrgullYVTfsDzJN6YIc9TMEzOSO_pSVmClCmyqKb2bNINRt2XpACCLVRkNpndpkk1Q>  


Google's De Castro To Yahoo


...that's what AllThingsD's Kara Swisher was hearing <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo1BGR0pYTrvtDfxh_A5XPADgoiJtdVMZAZ2sGIhVSy3nSSpmeBnDm_UIcW1MZZWJuJ8icw-BRnFxhMPcw_1LcZ6rpicE4Wqy1vo-lPYKGtzzrS_puGs2glXVks2Ckq18GCE3vx7P9VytKbo0eewOYh9R5iz4kX6bGkJ14NqCyni9BUJ6MlEPARilxhgTXBpPtihe0EEgxke2StIl6JXBcl956WKdEYfOKLR2HY_8q0hWJDm3snZxAnP> . And then word came down - Yahoo! has a new COO - Henrique De Castro, Google's former global head of media, mobile and platforms business. The New York Times reports, "Yahoo lured Mr. De Castro with a hefty pay package that according to a regulatory filing will include a $600,000 base salary plus a bonus that - depending how he performs - could be worth twice that much. Mr. De Castro will also receive $36 million in stock, half of that as a one-time retention equity award and the other half as performance-based stock options." Not bad. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo2Lx4FZen9GXWVilGYKr5hXQ-9b9j85Sfiv6tPHqHBq6NVXQy9KKZ8ReqQ8JRcMsiKJuXPbyYbN4bh6D30ECdP4z_b3HcEYSGUwIMgLMNdt6rK654-co-xmvN1_YMJilsSO_Bc-G8zZ_JpLhNTCBeY8fdh5ROb2jRYFMl4QKway37nFzRerlTpJmFIf4gKBsbK1g53ASbP5fKTvHghKIp7W> 


Native Ads Are Restless


Most publishers want to emphasize "premium sales" these days, and one big idea associated with that push is the creation of native ad units. The problem is that most agencies and marketers prefer standard ad units -- if only because they want to avoid the costly and time-consuming procrustean need to retrofit their banners to fit a unique placement. Jay Lauf, group publisher of The Atlantic Media Company, tells Digiday's Josh Sternberg that native ads can scale if the offering "centers around recognition of the assets you have to tell your stories [with], as well as flexibility in how they are used on the marketing side and trust on the publishing side." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001zoeEeNP2Xo1famxfRKkaEhvwsp1r1uzyDlXc3JhTksGfAdQUrSAr1LYgG8uOl0i3mJEuXBoICkOYD_yBfhNNfhfLmRZJa-7k9qS-jTnpvH1-w-KqSTpqLoxMVbQ0Tv6TrkVCJnRMulpYgqNz8EGTJevzmPpuzVRIpdouSXtlOTA=> .

Moat Sues ComScore


On PandoDaily, Erin Griffith reports on a counter suit by analytics firm Moat <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODZvCBCFc0R3_y83dH95axXpmC5lhbfiPHdQ_3S3L9DbIq5ZQCL6yjvCNtlL8VKiBdC2AGoQ_TYUpyHYOmLSSP8yJ0iSMRMpsao=>  against comScore after comScore had sued Moat in July <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODbEL6Ev4n4KYn7LHuDgrdji2_0fDKEHxyPNMP4KLAEZ558b3TUB9fM9ThJLAhjQIslSNri-ovW_C6kwsjJvpgKQDLdVk2906mDoMRBTalqg2BqPHzo4bm29G-bEqb5NDsYKxuOvr4NpB7XTOh6HutV-mAhD6bsYxJkh76u_SXO1dQ==> . Griffith writes, "Moat has also accused comScore of fraud. ComScore promoted a 'viewable impression' standardized form of measurement widely in the industry without disclosing, until now, that it holds a patent on viewable impressions. That's kind of a problem - the entire industry is spending money and energy supporting the IAB's Making Measurement Make Sense initiative and trying to make its products fit into that viewable impression standard." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODbWNWgTmj3evd-si2y1nZoTSfmCDa2SFv2nc7S79aM14rarSJ-ZCT-avrd67VnDnCOP0nNQCyyFJ-plRaDmIOFnaJeLiqMuYw7SohKvboF9NCvj32n9F4NRobzbsaC6p9ivFKyCPCm2fHBLKUYtOo52QZIwXMTM8mzH3rqlueVfssrwTfdVblJnGr53XkN3ZeRPZeMOHBGuAw0mWoInCm3V003N4R7uzDw=> 


Search Feels Amazon's Impact 


Google's Paid Product Listings business is showing some early growth in its new format. But Rob Schmults, SVP of strategic partnerships at Intent Media, points to some changes in the search marketing firmament that Google has long dominated. He tells Mediapost's Laurie Sullivan that because Amazon allows advertisers to directly target product searches through a cost-per-click model, it is essentially "taking money out of Google's pocket." Hence, Google's decision to ramp up PLAs. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODYQOXAkIBWrYW_vTqa8psbYG6c4He-wlf94YiJtqmgxX91tdT99XxSFGWaRadbEccWO-fv6xr50j0bqUnqkP166BwG9cPPD0GP-TsvgvlvV4u859HGRbqcS9_GQLbPGgca4v4YCNr1gJszU9GI3PZcnKZfjhb_nGI4ysY8ot-yH0khIxw38cXiDAPQqZMC-kbGmW0JEjj06QWRydpWQdHW0_dUH_JxsuaIbHJ4DZZ_asinwUhQvWGdl286N7hih5BfbDaawf26XSA==> . 


AOL (Still) Plotting Comeback 


As earnings season comes upon us, AOL is looking a little better in investors eyes thanks to stabilizing traffic, Bloomberg's Edmund Lee reports. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODbiVSVsN_jAWDFMXamzz7LB6JUIyHGIDYruYbVHvH-WFAT7zaBi2_lWsZrC_5MAVxJ29NoOk3ccGqvZFcgzcNXlFMk_lmYuavtULQOQx6qTyJUou_SkcHZLLdC1luxBrQKb4tm5Rw_hM1q3NpEYOZe582037MuW8fJ5C0VHRZZgGNLBD0WrW1Ji8U9qhro9NfT8okZI7-ZyLaUQUY9niYeN> . But revenues are still lagging. That said, AOL's position could be worse. "AOL is further along in their turnaround than Yahoo is," says ThinkEquity's Ronald Josey. And, it's stock price has more than doubled in a year <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODarTk-FiA8R3pgP-O2R_A3Z02GH7bgbBhT1JCNxaio21nV_QYhIg5R968kROap-6u8ebEOE3Q4hPR-YeyyeXeGDBBucAuU4zRzCTb8yrYNxFCazFs8WM-lujKn3W4xh3WAzLt1mKQBaTYz4w9MBWjpx> . 


Showrooming


When your online rivals are selling the same stuff for less, what's a brick-and-mortar retailer to do? Best Buy thinks it can ramp sales and prevent so-called "showrooming <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODbn7teeX8xO8TjnKDfv75Tr1aJMc0vCEPhyR0o5u_bynYNJL5UO5ZvVwDKafu6gCtUYB6gHBti2tp9gl0F5dWSyy_1GFmgoJn7Nrid_vAW3wI8_hujQ0nLHBPVMl0BVVesElyMgEuG1P0ab_dvV9pkPiiO3bpaQmB8=> " by matching online competitor prices this holiday season. The Wall Street Journal's Ann Zimmerman notes the contradiction, "Aware that [traditional retailers] need to adapt aging business models to the realities of mobile- and computer-aided shopping, they don't want to overreact or lose sight of what made them successful-that is, selection and service." Read more (subscription). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODa3qCHxQK8qt5_aoUTsmAjZakDxt3Fi0ZX1j_YNM77WgiidU9dk6DCaJOQ85UU4lJY6nYhDT1NUUGyTjwHjHvE7iAcsUoRHINgZoyFyX4dmz7ZyBmTdDIHCl9WYs7KCalCmmiwON1GDgmPfx2Yfgwa1xIOkDFT73g6phHEAWSBX-nWgRkc7VJPZ>  


I Was iFramed 


Cross-domain iframes have thrown a wrench in the viewability debate, which already had a few toolboxes worth. Spider.io is the latest company to claim it has solved the issue, which exists because browsers don't let scripts communicate between iframes on different domains. Read the press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODa0KPgPLT1ythdN5qHI1vdthlbPLHMxfX2HmoCjWeNhcZT05upxEgohz_DS0dxlYmSxpBeEigKXYkp_1lGpfMjLOyYdCm_w_EGzAv_tpNjrJEhf3889y9NIK5xYcOfxU1kYtm-xf0_Zxhkl2A-JzeB1ErlX6mUeQEzvwZGtmeyJo9OvuOeGLQbJCLMjYFwZ8pZb2BAyeHX9TpzQHgOKg660QBAuyetRuD9AyoPsUpfEs1dXrTxdxEB7LfXz-ch9Xe0Tcq95SoFGLg==>  And, more on Ad Operations Online <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODaa1SVduq1mbASD6xy7uQ39uZX8P8dLZ34l7_nB3Co2iawLKqK533KjTnQnzBlmvXf2bWdQCNfK5-vbP_E-ApUg3DwnihBQRqEvkG8dTSKbvkFvPSAxKFpEx5WUwy4JkfB0Pci5iPB4hCXIpxz8RSHD8Oyw71bruTGven5GDq5soYxCEbvPyJwFV6kU3vCign3RZjHQ7bGxT0n2o0yK1gThEbtPVA37EaeZe5C95oZqoknCfMthqFjJdBgr8lElRL3v4AmsMsdPV_3KnjPx2Xi6Jshqn66WKsea6ouwf3c5FAPWmnruPf2XtCsEtQg-PAY=> .

Big Bucks for Windows 8 Launch 


Microsoft may have earmarked as much as $1.8 billion for its Windows 8 launch campaign, says Dave Einstein of the branded NetApp blog on Forbes.com. If true it's historic money. Einstein: "That's the biggest product launch in the history of the industry; it dwarfs the $200 million Microsoft spent to market Windows 95." He cites Microsoft analyst Rob Enderle, who states, "the marketing effort is on a scale you don't see outside presidential elections." Could be a chance to show faith in audience buying and drop a pile of cash on "programmatic premium" through AppNexus. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001OuJk4nlJODY47W91vu9LBc9PCZBNiwn_gYhCxtFPCgsUQncTCgH47pGU3C2_eIzOCMy2Kkxoeg7eyFYL9v1ngi2GBvH3Y_96xnlbp3towJ8fGFuKm5RksgFiZy-wbKh_h3aciGWOnirZr6qPyetI3Qxr5kpLfWGPrll5y_Wm9mWGuiTmMXcVEka_nMDIhBMtv5B8UCNUEaMeJ6PYTfreMTRlN_ucpUwTkBrKvykF9e8=>

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email? Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCwcrriYO0UQvTPV7A36Ozrge--K8wNJ18uT5EU1lBUbDuTWVJyInZe8dRnDxDxNTzR2FH_Y3N8qXdCDCDKn1TRtB3mraIPTH8bEwSKGzFiBKFIRcEYPRUTEh8lPcd7pbZ78=> .

 

IAB: Another Historic Rise


The first half of 2012 presented yet another record-breaking period for online ad spending, says the Interactive Advertising Bureau, as marketers lavished $17 billion on the web between January and the end of June. Things looked pretty good during Q2 as well, as spending rose 14 percent. The key drivers, as they have been for the past few years, has been video and mobile. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCwdWfD4tUcmv77AIMa5oI8i_MUAi-toaaqACGW1ora0pCg0l-t7dnpyI5nL9Hnwzlpt-mUFbMEsX4wcnLqJ-G9BPBtGUcREXA_YTUwD0KKsH-ic9WBYwRY2QWT-sStcyrnOjIwnXIEOfgaUA7MQVglVJkY2FhO03f-HH7GUNehr0cN9kMCyKbAQEesRCHxUBf7-W5dOG6jn9o8BZc5my1DlZ> . Separately, Wall Street analyst Brian Wieser was contrarian: "New data from the IAB confirms - contrary to the industry's underlying narrative - broad weakness for publishers across the Internet advertising industry in the United States." 


Native Ad Cash


"Native video ad" platform Sharethrough announced a new $5 million round of funding. Read the release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCwcOKEey8_tKMn7wlZb3EuSyQoqf5EzOOmqC1h3oIHLaRruC8bGpbRSezqsv806odXrWFvYNInRnHgS8CIiD5NP6gL8O5zB2mxI_1kN-bTmTuEyG1n3yEhbeOgZY2Fz5_9Lh8gEBqDVxzQf2iReLSoZwYm_6uyojg65cyJuWOoyq4gkj61cN73et1IdbPBTpT-LEy-4ANKKvhcqez8MYOfhlfG92nPnFvjGDAPHdew7-vI7RaH3I-iF6>  Tim Peterson covers the news on Adweek and talks to the company's CEO: "While native advertising isn't an easy sell to media buyers who typically prefer traditional buying methods, the online video advertising startup has grown its revenue 87 percent year over year, and [CEO Dan] Greenberg expects Sharethrough to pull in $40 million in revenue next year." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCweeYvil2XIwwFDGFhM0Gdq4GbCk77eEII6MwEv6bYxLKZCv9TMeZPuFhnDTOKI_DXBV0vv_eBSP_TrZe3NfOlrEU0J8rn_yJAonexNWk27yogwYWLNGf9oo1EvovnHjg8MxCwNOrvIOBxmadd9bzlOoW6tOL6xsbLBekm5IQYk-w_MaQtxRXL2WBMBbdOlpIiBMbI7gXIpHrg==>  


YouTube's Gangnam Style


Since this summer, unlikely Korean pop star Psy's infectious video for his song "Gangnam Style" has dominated YouTube. BTIG Analyst Rich Greenfield looks at the numbers of views the video has garnered and compares it to a hit network TV show. Furthermore, the virality of the video appears to have opened up the Google-owned video site to new advertiser categories. "Beyond A-List advertising, we also saw something we had never seen on YouTube before (unclear how new/not new this is), but we saw a pre-roll video ad for a local furniture store, screenshot embedded to the right (Gramercy Vintage Furniture)," Greenfield writes. "We suspect locally targeted ads have a very significant CPM." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCwcb8961gfh91zYYyAKnV3YuomJzE3VIXeIRwfHpj_Up8Wp_j-MktSdPb9UFp8uiv-hAkV--6bVb9sF_vcfJTYwrSXx4omy6CA7QPdyTXvVW-RRvdhK2htBLnkGdOFhs8MZhpf_ozwV4AR1rH0mxV0gIe97TjGfvmwgEcBmt5rq54BEPlvQRHuf_TGjBLVuhe_sc4_4CAVCIk3bg7SpwsAdfYHLGuu97hqZwddvpH7GkIDwlqJ5PHJKJNe0GlxC-cekf9H-mN55q6A==>  [sub. req.]. 


Facebook's Custom Ads


Techcrunch's Josh Constine has taken a look at the results of Facebook's three-week-old Custom Audience Ads and so far, the results appear pretty positive. The ads, which targets consumers via lists of emails or phone numbers, are "not as amazing as Facebook Exchange retargeted ads, but they boost clicks and conversions, reduce costs, and deliver ROI according to Facebook and three adtech startups," Constine writes. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCwdPuxQXBnhcP6_aerSMBCDw9huPC4M9cfl74D9uWN7P_oX3BWE4OQ6eT6UnZGdsBe8DmYOFavOFklggXETh8x7372ju5Uhr6qsvR1b3QAf52P-cTfz84yAI2xeEwvOgJdk7Fn1YqI_5IXQvH2SxRH2NqfEPM1eNgtVWJuQ87bgy4Q==> . 


Display The Brand


In an opinion piece on Digiday, Criteo's Jonathan Wolf looks at demand generation with display. He writes, "...a lot of branding display dollars online are really performance dollars pretending to be something else. Since advertisers have not been able to replicate the branding impact of TV ads, they have inevitably switched to focus on performance - an area where online reigns supreme. Unfortunately, this has been challenging for traditional display, since its performance is so much weaker than demand-fulfillment channels like search." He thinks this is beginning to change. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCwcf2sj4R8XStwEXKrTJCfZYj1bDqdjvA5ErRd0j3OP4J5bIlH0CWpeDhpKIbRthI9jCjSbLdd4s16_NyEnAqVcbE-hb679IkqkIAJoRCswUOdYmGhi517iWV6Tt97LlvhyKFNSZzZGaqNr7jRleSMHeAwg1dRjBACfEJAP4rQ6xmA==>

RTB Audience


On MediaPost, Operative CEO Mike Leo talks programmatic selling ands says a recent publisher survey by his company shows publishers are none too pleased with real-time bidding (RTB). He writes, "Almost across the board, publishers told us that RTB was a place to park inferior inventory. 'On sites with strong brands and great content, context trumps audience,' one VP told us. 'On crap sites,' he continued, 'What else do you have but audience to try and raise CPM?'" Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCwczckMx8eR7jSU08wQjt_AxSEui8fKjTgo-bfJ6twy_cDEQurO4XyOsFP_Wg9rdSJNOQUvwO8D3hSx6ktQCdzyT3WD1RYIb6sMPa9QbTE47AJupPojM8xZ0XYsBDG90NnroajKi17MEBjEtxJbzEjZ4c33JWWKNCiQntG377ZZZSc3ZYhvyOLuv5YhOfVR7zU1VjBTQBz2ye0g0VMnBhRgm>  


Yahoo's Possible Plans


Yahoo CEO and new mom Marissa Mayer called an "all hands" meeting for Thursday and AllThingsD's Kara Swisher has a lot of guesses about what she may have been discussing. Among the many possibilities is the likelihood of some big acquisitions. Yahoo has apparently considered buying Criteo (home to Yahoo ad sales head Greg Coleman), Mediaocean (which is headed by former Right Media head Bill Wise) and Turn. "But my money would be on PubMatic, if there is an acquisition," Swisher says. "The Silicon Valley company would be a solid add to Yahoo's ad platform offerings, especially if it wants to stay competitive with Google." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCwfJ4t8nZcZoT-QFHo7Q5e-Ec98YDTOASt4wpTYukYuH4yYOR55TVfixX8zUbLI6eEjLLjsigUHikZI_tK5Fdu95IiGOxrQm0GCgnWjwiU7IxKXB1U2TjycImdPZ3YgC2Bg9v415o3_DSom6CITy4rM6mEzhcn1jwdw8fGYJ5NyhLb5lywr-kTl4hz8ouc30hlh4mayUHIl9nVeqk8VR5mURegH9wmdAwFhn1KI5e8acFm69JHlmocgTTkfLAk8hOsNFtri94bScyg==> . 


Big Gov Looks At Big Data


Sen. John D. Rockefeller IV (D-W. Va.) is investigating nine information brokers to understand whether the "unprecedented amount" of personal, medical and financial information about people could be collected, mined and sold - and what the impact would be on consumers, the NYT's Natasha Singer reports. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCwd5GOQvvaPmcPBIVVMCw3K2Ybj0qYWExTWJQDy6-ROD-kNxqfL8Cw-5KdG43R3klDSj_nsB89BNWKgIaPQ2BfLNKBZ40sd-rkz5J3peNlsTHsNddsWZwZGEZkIa_dH22EIkeBLi5NwbiAtEeUxpFFzPKW6apU9XCP9FhgD3TQc7nlZyIHL8zGciFYLY3Ed8icYpQ1etBUH0EXmhSN9hqSHo0NsDgUqJt6w=> . Linda Woolley, the acting head of the Direct Marketing Association, has her own concerns about the senate investigation. "I hope Senator Rockefeller understands what he's tampering with," she said. 


Programmatic China


GroupM's Xaxis announced the launch of its audience buying platform in China yesterday. From the release, some logistics: HQ will be in Shanghai and Beijing and "The China division will be led by Rajesh Sukhwani who will serve as managing director, Xaxis China. Sukhwani was previously director, global business development for Xaxis." There's programmatic business developing in China. Read the release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001l9nzHEycCwcnArPjeYxxyoPKb8qpw7g_N9lYkT-zav6AjJyPQ36j9fY_EcNLZnmdW3gRQPeFMybbtHugn2QzviKTER17bGjhEbmCUZ6Y90IB29GBTTkwOjcHgL1lo2P_fU7huyxjucpRIauJfGr50rCbrjlK49TEBim9hZs7YHJ3DBAWBta7o1ueQkaQHZAKipGyujoLU14VtJOpyHK4EpQeZwo1tkWN0c1AX_QH8LiP9ScddMJQzA==>

UK's Mobile Ad Rocket


Mobile ad spend is hitting warp speed in the UK as a new report reveals triple digit growth. The Guardian reports, "Breakneck growth is continuing in the second half - fuelled by the popularity of Apple and Google's app stores as smartphone ownership nears 60% of the UK's adult population - with forecasts putting UK mobile spend at as much as £511m for the full year. In 2011, the IAB put mobile ad spend at £203m <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3OZu3IUdoD8cQV_ZUfca13Zhzu2TxnU4umHIfVQuOpGZcKS8aAHh_Da0JM-p_ZDda5k3dwyPO1QVpBiYlu_cyVgG6X_xsR46Zvoa7qf2_eP6q3ucSGhgcQSe7-mI-McJCqvKlVyAJMrjA9oLGqyGHhuJOsWhqy9S393Zm7ufDhBaQ==> ." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3POtOMOmmoQOrpoLeYVvtgb91_RXv4pH5oUMbE9ibSMhMKQoEp-BopaACL2vxb0IG9bHmbtWDHDMCoW9P-zyn20kvE8JtbxCG_xuR5hm6we5moJfarTiofspRaZCJti4BE0xQD4LeteUh1hcQQcJvTATm1QGjbFWcTa1-5CS27nkA27BkODKmsGu5or12m_DYE39MxZM66Q0Q==>  


More on Facebook Verticals


Facebook has added sales & marketing staff in a number of vertical categories. Brittany Darwell of InsideFacebook observes job postings have included retail, e-commerce, automotive, CPG/beverage, entertainment, travel, mobile/finance, tech/socialcom and gaming over the past year. "Facebook aspires to play an advisory role for brands and other advertisers so it needs to understand the objectives in each market." Read more.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3PbN2ubnoUiiqzjHOOirSA9cNEna9Ovd-l3YOoHBXb-GIZMAQV-I-gla_pAIO2cRMjDcNcGpDz9aopfTFDWMoGdhDm0-GMdM7VFaCoKeifjrq2E_Bp_8cWPqHJ7iGXZAiFbSda1g_-Meiatduk3tZfpOIs2uh8Mx6GCedPLG-5bmyzZ7gaipZS8ye7_hBdFOwT_U5S7OvDR8bPdP0xrNuVrClqAg7geNLqO5zHYEG5JOQ==> 


Client Goes Direct


Client and agency roles continue their shift. On Digiday, Kellogg's Aaron Fetters talks about how they go right to the vendor with their requirements for analytics. No agency here. Fetters: "We will do our best to give requirements like what our business objectives are from an analytics standpoint. Then, we will reach out to the industry and understand what we can get out of a partnership. That's how we treat it, as a partnership, and not just a vendor. We'd like to work with someone we can learn from, someone who can let us influence the direction of their product. We want a two-way commitment." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3Pr7_LrqJ5RvE2LBmotH-xLGMH9y_OE0h9PohMl9UVlIQlkLLCaw52OQVlRTzb8tpkZV3SwGk8ovf6vHLScPd8HfdvWVrDNtPn8ojj3CkHuqplgPdbib9SpGz9zguxNzBnClba6thMW6psg9OmhqGEnAe-nqjFenqs=>  


Dynamic FBX Creative


Adweek covers the increasing use of dynamic creative on Facebook Exchange. "Starting last month, AdRoll has been trialing dynamic creative with a handful of clients and alternating the dynamic creative equally with static ads. Since then, AdRoll has seen, on average, a 102 percent higher clickthrough rate (CTR) than the static ads, said Berke. Since FBX ads are bought on a cost-per-thousand-impressions basis, the dynamic ads cut advertisers' cost per click in half, he said." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3M--_CFuhw_1ZCzcfhIeU0G54ut0rH-6BXZqk90XxrhKsO7i2aWqQgkjB6LVECfrfrF7bMutM9rk_j8XCziZfG2ExyyAh9IwkzuTRX4ggAuQcZZddI2FyyIaHsXdpiwV2Pj-o8m665qpHWaCEFkg0PrceAk2EJo2WjwliE-17rshpPwYe9fgZicDVRii1LbnrV0juW50DPpAA==> . 


Trading Standards


VivaKi Nerve Center's Marco Bertozzi wonders aloud on his personal blog regarding who's responsible for making sure ads run in the right places. He writes, "So bearing in mind that the Police think the advertiser should take responsibility, the advertiser thinks the agency should, the agency thinks the Trading Desk should and the Trading Desk thinks the suppliers of inventory should we have a beautiful example of sequential liability (without all the legal jumbo jumbo!) - I took a decision." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3PzZ1cLAOpwMtZKVPFPbP3wHLW9d36aDCh8MIIfAFbMzBx0D2lSvXO6yBXbah8JCRbFD369-POp4iwxAhc7qGCKvMKZm39DCugp2Fr0tSvv8tLG1eN6oMMYd0rIlSnGAXn3tZMfC6ZKE_84t_gb33yjgo73fGE5X55Qj2ZJh1Pls2CJeQ5T3VGN0G8HQyssWzA=>

Planet Of The Ad Tech


On his Upstream Group blog, Doug Weaver wades in with a "premium" point-of-view on ad tech while impressively tieing in a reference to Planet of The Apes. Weaver chides towards the close, "In the end, who is really served by an industry built on infinite cheap impressions and endless levels of commodity management, optimization and targeting? It's not the marketers, agencies or publishers. It's really just the speculators. And when the air finally comes out of the ad-tech bubble, how many of those speculators will still be engaged in the hard work of building an industry with us?" Thousands! Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3ORrTAQDVs5e7UALj1af2SG6PS2eFEBmexC-ANsjnrKvV6bWCQNGGH-OHr4ShcKt5t4dK-Af9pSMevsqsRbkzBwLhv5vrpSmVtU_CBLmvK9_FatYaPTvCsmSRQbJ4qm2fEeFL4882KgPw==> . 


Datalogix Scrutiny


In the wake of Datalogix's PR-tastic pairing with Facebook (AdExchanger summary <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3Pe2DyUVzkDiORwK2SlwZpezi-PIskZLwfkZdIl2OrxnTqxoFB2kCDiy2QmNxakPEvtZprs6Zajc-fW0dli0P3j_F4ZByfo9JMXTiSPNmUHTvhbvdyYpV21LEf08lMyjteM5GNOmmg5-fmHXEBPOvvWb4ytn63crA8=> ), the two companies are getting some unwanted attention from U.S. Senator Jay Rockefeller. As ClickZ's Kate Kaye reports, Rockefeller wants to know what data they collect and how it's used. The letter also went to Acxiom, Epsilon, Equifax, Experian, Rapleaf, and others. absent from the list are firms doing essentially the same thing Datalogix is enabling for voter files that support political campaigns. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3OrDC09omvNYxFcmpiY6RkNAJkLX9b9kazDEdVbZMQzlB1_WkOfGDau8SA3h7bD_3Yyw5sBpevPk4bt8EiUjSxFKNjxhFYZkd8r3IXzRUL81btrWoNRzBklnyd3oSrpB7wImPs3_Visu6N3mTXYH2ZSSTkIpGUnwbSpDfA4440QX3OULTy2Rp7a7jR4TpXkvAU=>  


Backup GIF, Please


On AdMonsters, Maria Tucker explores the backup GIF. Rememeber those pesky little backups to the flash units? Well, there still in play, in fact they're growing in use. She writes, "This uptick in backup .gifs can be directly attributed to the explosion of mobile device use. According to Marcus Pratt, Director of Insights and Technology at Mediasmith <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3NyhcvQkBr5r73329yhk_Y8dQgwYWroZWbKBRC3_6MkC2qxzFEw_ul6LHcANu1VkGETzlxlZ0Ee8m5-gvj499YoOrAmyVLk-4GrxrhsPMOxcQ==> , because of this increase in mobile and tablet browsing, 'impressions served to devices without flash can be 10% or higher for some campaigns.'" Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0012OszbDKGH3PNJc6RiU56c2HxdrfBlqMbIlbWzoqL3l3Gy-vGwLxM7PPHu3-71t4zr5Plc8T-bbGDNpoCBeGz7PPzlDahmr6g6v5Y9GE6kNYQiF6GHAxGNIZIQWXfzaTrzRUH8UnGPRqvVoaRXxJ9O0yUCI2BCCCkih_TSVBNnqs=> .

DNT Off The Rails?


Is the Digital Advertising Alliance the industry coalition that kicked the hornets nest? With new guidance exempting members from honoring "Do Not Track" in IE10 (AdExchanger story <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qPv2hODYf9tL6IBbHk06wSHmWKj8VvPKX1p5uwpBfTMnrHqFW--GRi0gDDOIJ0ifvT3TtIWfMKchwd6ey0GsA2FpU1RZ-u1ygnghxKVqI_GrIZtZ8wETD3V3TJIEK-s7vE_fxMrwNN4euBeQ6LkgNwZKLc0SlGlefF6MpQ9BHa4D3shPxgLQ5wNFqwnqTw9EnxNC6wHbMipqw==> ), the DAA has inflamed privacy advocates -- to put it mildly. "DAA is trying to turn DNT into TNT and blow the process up," Center for Digital Democracy's Jeff Chester tells the National Journal. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qMnJg_8ZQwjd8zDO3LCy4KfLeHy26LDnPAxCUQgVgPC_haX9BwayZZeFGfsxQux09dhhO0WJnplnHotLaD8aCBfcn_rAIWq4lsEyO1CCZcJARzyUpa_ra-vTI6IILr3jfZ_PRi2WJfdbxRL9F0Xy164owq8mCqQgAaU2yz38Xf825zONrRB_r8u_kBseqZxzrE=> . More coverage: The Next Web <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qNeAd6QVv0OcCLmIEl305cEdTlJHn9YZMGxz93SXW7CSce19RoQVivhiCM2vXsVo6PjLkkB9I_BJC6G3x0hEQFpYWlUT6BJVbrkppCCekUj16ekMt7GazXWkHu5iEwRNfOSkZi9rn62L39c-hL9qqXw>  and AdWeek <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qPBKjQetbX4PG4wSYIbDj1wrBUl2Y3_B_B_JUcD6a6wUimyNKhgN6CS5GDIXzkPgF61OOGHrGBhEsO9CbTelHpQh4lchDrBb5QBOl1Mx-qSEFHfNT9EBtuKp1XnNsAG0nW7eCF286bIYgGor5ZUDd4-dmuDPW9s2QS_CC8ilCpyz3FXHtestMYbqFaV6pBMqM_vOEQXFZxU7zfIc2-k6lESdmPzs0oCsGQ=> . 


Viewability & CPMs


A new online spending report shows big growth ahead in the ad exchange market as well as growing CPMs. But, what kind of growth? Ad Age's Jason Del Rey takes a look at the study and explains, "The bad news is that this CPM increase will be largely driven by adoption of the 'viewable impression <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qMfbojQS1E7H8yyCVylcA1pw_LOLdDhrqe3T6_bKOydzxLCuP-RPJ9v4fU_ciUqPiQM0X3a3Pdn7sJfsogbpMWx9oPd6URe7bexYMYRhu1mR4yZiJrtXUcFd_lyT22s2XpQzEnyltho8nkvHuRpMiNIZU0nwuz4aZ_7qHa3PcZS-DlNqwkHlVCMh8EnKwqSwzMy0Ilz6uR8Fg==> ' standard, where advertisers pay only for for ads that are visible on the screen. For a lot of publishers this will mean fewer impressions, which could offset some of the CPM gains. Indeed Forrester's estimate assumes a 17% compound annual growth rate in overall online ad revenue, down from the 20% it predicted last year." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qONG8TnuDaoFcDjRRztapCWKPYJy2wLYHaVUUqOxZWPsE7Ko7n30_YxrjC2m7eN-qqxilwy-kQnlh7GH3dpM76Ka-udGLIFDfwaNuVmTjXuzq0kVPSieJgHL7wnDspK2_vQfr7jCKYpSPVcALLOr50xN6mTA13AVhHUHa8atnqLvNn_BmYlegi-Bs03wQYpHe1L-k5M_GzCHA==>  


Facebook Desire Data


Facebook is testing a wishlist feature with some big retailers including Pottery Barn and Victoria's Secret. As reported by Reuters, the offering sounds a little like Pinterest as it "will allow certain users to flag images of desired products by clicking a special 'want' button." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qOVTNTBpejP4gFmv2GicL2boswZN_2J1gUVHEMtclPvgK546xPgralWBvQjy8qDmfLGTATVvp5ngwyVYIxl3t87rjyOcdyixrdcJ26d9O-_5g55xAjBgq7voOqtaF4nZJ8uLcbYfGJ4W6tF0Btd3YyNsLcUWLTZY2HjUk-HdKPC7KvpT4Hz3gJpHG9kyOnBIvE=>  According to a Facebook statement, "People will be able to engage with these collections and share things they are interested in with their friends. People can click through and buy these items off of Facebook." More: AllThingsD. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qNm3CHFKDjbm2fFhdD1bOMPd2ft7f2xfrNDtG24W93T8fETxrjUt6yks4wZMiMoiiX7RY-Xrx_Mutg4nExmUSl2yCybB6Ld949_RSwFsMkhi09RuuQDWgkTn4Vqa8ScrPMey68IGI-v7mbzld83vUhrNSLi7jPkWCVPx8Bs9AfMW4Ode1fKujatjBnjSTcwI2uIySSj5TlkYKN9EuD2N33FdruRJBhe18yrgFy_d3ZQCQ==>  


RTB's Primetime Moment


To consumers, all screens are pretty much created equal, right? Well, advertisers are still having trouble with the full-on cross platform concept, but they're getting there. Writing in Mediapost, John Osborn, head of media consultancy The Next Generation, had dialogue with TubeMogul's VP or marketing Keith Eadie about how real-time bidding is going to open up TV advertising across all video devices. "Whether the marketer's purchase funnel strategy is focused on the top (branding), middle (developing consideration) or bottom (promoting action), these advances in buying and OTT are softening the silo walls between the various traditional responsibilities for media placement - a good thing," Osborn says. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qM_r_R5Ysm2NW3_PpNL1WT2cB-b8r-Ad1XNMWT6MVVamkS3JRls2EhRnOdCk65Ajg6mWoEAxqGTVYxv7ReainJSakQOJzSX-azv6SeVubI35ib20SSNjE7EKHv5q_WuqUe4RKQ_ZGYQvjZmrs-UZsibjfm9WgojgcVqqpWhf0rmVkJNVEeld41Gw4oWSYkGuwypdODeF3b4CRTBEqCpCzvL8tR48KfpJCU=> . 


Audio Ethno-Ad Targeting


The growth in the U.S. Hispanic population -- and the concomitant consumer power that comes with such a rise -- has made Latinos an attractive target for advertisers generally. Adweek's Christopher Heine looks at the contrasting targeting abilities of the two major music streamers, Pandora and Spotify, and finds that the former is zeroing in on Hispanics, while the latter can't do that level of ethnic identification. "I may love Spanish songs but am not Hispanic...We therefore don't offer Hispanic targeting currently," says Spotify VP Jon Mitchell, arguing that the notion doesn't really make sense to the company. "We have been asked to-but not currently." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qMh0jk4kmybe9LaosNBXTHY90km_FknN9PWRZ6BtVMNbvAN0juAi-u2eR8OgePLreZPY7Ok-Dyi11TToso_HDrsXlpGwuEJ4wE5VFNYtOTX6r9tGJVeUbe7RHBqcbNtQWziZa3RT_6NR7Xbuzv52HV7hIEHQdBwjVku3-ZMaAKnpsUZbf3w05KbDVDK_gFtfaZsa9EIvLA2JQ==> .

One-Stop Shop


Publishers have been dabbling in retail through e-commerce units, so why shouldn't retailers start making ad sales on their websites a part of their business too? Smaller retailers and startups are joining that trend, pioneered by the likes of Amazon and Wal-Mart, reports San Francisco Business Times' Patrick Hoge. Burke Johnstun, co-op advertising and media manager for e-tailer Overstock.com noted that there is a delicate balancing act in selling goods and selling ads. "We want to make sure we don't cannibalize our main efforts," he said. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qN2v4H3LFScoa7dqtpkXiZSz9SeOSlFnQSfcVmI-_YEvLW4ytDd-E_nRkP156k-EBQVgtz88JMsRCAkyNO6-X8X6uBjFnIzhERGW0bwe955O1StuuRl4_nHgdXOEbzKKsNYoh1YRbgBi5cuWRO2EGMcmOsXR5-YT9FpodNd8d9Tc95m4mMR_Kx2bMD28dImTtE7gI2W2--tLVqw3Wu6nk_q> . 


Social Search


From The Voice of Russia comes fun gossip that Facebook and Yandex may be doing something on social search. It's all based on Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's rumored, personal visit to Yandex HQ recently and.. a job posting... VOR writes, "The job description gives an impression that Yandex is looking for someone to lead a team of developers to creating an easy to use search that would aggregate these topics and opinions. Google and Yandex already have blog searches and limited social network searching functionality. What the job description hints at looks more like an extensive monitoring tool, actually - kind of like the one the Russian government is using." Nyet way! Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qPsk6rwqvxkCD_KVTK2MliNLm9ODvc-W_5LndhFyMVznEdrL9Un76_7LJrhfs_InrtEmm_Woi_YufTZJ0q5SjX8RxVUMQNh4ZOoHDvNrXMMz78sk4QE3dAnbMWcxrzkLTufpwvJOLAWBXFRPaqGcpJ033yKe1ARLMs=>  


The Privacy Dashboard


PrivacyChoice, purveyor of privacy tools for publishers and end users, launched a browser plugin to help people grapple with their privacy decisions. "Privacyfix challenges you to take about 10 minutes to make the most important privacy choices you have about Facebook, Google, the websites you visit and the companies that track you." Blog post. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Lu-3jlr11qNRZCe2rdl3GedSaFEvQMjZoQecbULZXbXMBogGDHaA_YRWr4ndOh__cEzl2ecqRb9gjEkhoa5OdwB4gGxDtx2L3_BXapkmpqXMDIPTfilLssnS0Lvpc_XzA0gHUiajTY6jd5z0McHj-W6AdBYhG3DzuwMhfWKcKYwOJyqj89_rgw==>

P&G's Mobile Ad 'Secret'


Procter & Gamble's deodorant brand, Secret, is running mobile ads on teen publishing site The Chic Fashionista that look to combine "engaging" marketing elements with Facebook and Twitter content that promote an anti-bullying message. The campaign, dubbed "Mean Stinks," uses ad tech firm Kontera's PageLift dynamic content mobile ad unit. "Mobile ads have become fairly simple with text and imagery, full-screen images, and layered in interactivity and rich media - at this point there is not a lot of innovation," said Ammiel Kamon, Kontera's EVP and head of mobile, tells Mobile Marketer's Chantal Tode. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J93q6MnKQyF4lHGlin3WDKNUyU0OQZ26Z1pLY3mq12UJ8Frx1fOzfHbO0PAXIBVkuhBjT6tipmzxT91dHCHgyJ4lSIeZ116jyEX9qxFqk27m3ekBXBI2c9PCLpxQSA9x6rc2tli_m2QHXkvlKCfAaIRZpXObix1ZpEM=> . And, read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J93oR5svKMMxEKrrnFWi206vwlp6Ac1ZrA25yOF0gv9BrE9-bcUWcwiHZgjrzmhrgCUrhs6wvUCc_1HZXxJCW30PGY8bRXO_FxvZViQBRBeUS-pynm0xQbJMNEhsHaXuHhV-6ad4-VtMLYGZWP0Ekbi7nSUk8-HNjWHXKVob1r4deCpZRlMd-xeaiLrTzePFeD3E13JwZhoO9nSRUK_amonypRV3Ev2V9TU=> . 


Human RTB


In a new study by Advertising Perceptions on behalf of Casales Media's new Index sell-side platform, it appears that the humans running the show are the key (can you say, "Human Centered Automation <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J92rHkbUdEXTCbvK6QLz_NTQZTTVBBu7pSe9EQDlWULRX0Y2WmDgsb00uC5Pb_vYdsOcrko-XHtbgg0e7F3jujrozQ0zbyULlVz2LlgaiM4erXcQ_SLhMTsUa9S6GdK23d4=> "!?). From the study, "Advertisers and publishers are relying on the human element in programmatic ad buying and selling to drive the growth of RTB and private exchanges. With half of advertisers and publishers trying RTB, both sides expect significant spending growth in this segment over the next 12 months." Read the release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J92LzZMGtm327G_WydeTEMRM2qi6_9bfgnvDz9nV71AFNRy0HSagWKliX8pxh0l8gu5d5Gqinc7jxODWLArPpg0CxMspdOfW4gkDTfdVk4ri8KoUsgrPb2KJIWTvkbQixrMRTGbJr1RWK-b9POcb8cR5RdG3r5YHxCCTrBONkYyaMdtiMEVFfieKFVIvsnxuyzL16x4XXQJLLv6mzFtssQL6GNpvliHXaBCVqlUfwQrCd8At9KPMOIFX>  And, download the report (PDF). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J93e2u84RIlQ4H31KhnhNZRz7pIaFpX75jwnLqGcKOxwwSCOCS8D3ZoDcFGlYm0DdfEIrTphOFoY6LKBxvL_U0Lr2I8DxSzOt0Xh-EoTAdNV0L5KuBCS-6Ij5Oc6MVvPmOnDN916XSBlRA==>  


Biz Dev Tips


comScore's Kirby Winfield offers hot-off-the-stove, ad tech-related, biz dev tips in a post on his personal blog. He begins with "Treat a signed agreement like a qualified lead - Biz dev is a lot like venture capital investing. In my experience, if you sign ten deals, five will fail outright, three will contribute de minimus returns but add strategic value, and two will pop and become true revenue contributors. That means you need to treat each deal signing as a qualifying stage and keep the pressure on post deal. " Read 'em all! <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J91bXCZ81tGLGgkhosEBmYSoAdxEL6_uAa2YivxXTD15xUnJ7nUqizACXdoCWDdW2IQ-veaADkWel0E9fp82IBO93gWXpkO0laCoQfwrrj9UHM1xREodRA7EaWFt57sdG55evfj0xu_Oh-586L262A4YOwvWY_bzOBjFRIQLlicLsLpcH4aAf6pC>  


CPG Quant Blues


It goes without saying that CPG marketers need young analytical talent, but the startup siren siphons many bright b-school grads, writes AdAge's Cotton Delo. "The very best analytical minds are apt to quaver at the thought of being pigeonholed at a traditional marketer with a narrow job description where they might be tasked with managing the discounts given to retailers, for example." Wharton prof Peter Fader says his brightest customer analytics students go into consulting and investment banking. More.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J93vR7syFzQeOdcPD49cs1w49B9aoFQhCTtiGexbft6msumY8LO9xhqn4z-lJeP0Tijc87Jm9nIlFb1aGFZFd6gxTd_aXVU-z3SfYuPUhzfM1GXCgAoMsm_OYKZK4yeZTYswDp2khcFF6Qxz4OOX6H6wE4rLJ--YLS-pGfK99D4XkGQA_ZqNCxThxlmQZcO9KwM=> 


FBX Europe


In Europe, ad exchange/marketplace Hi-Media says it can now offer access to the Facebook Exchange. Talking about its independent marketplace, CEO Cyril Zimmerman says in the release, "The inventories of the Facebook Exchange platform are added to the 20 billion Ad impressions already available through Hi-Media Ad-eXchange. The Group's marketplace promotes the audience of websites that are in the top 300 most important in each of the 9 European countries where the Group operates." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J90ZYoedKp_szbLvCq2u6duHBw55NrOMn2Kgo8Pkf1Phi9m7Kh9vm2W62QEtoYwRdJzoCoFii_Mq1ioWdJ24yPKiPsCsZbOfcrsqsBxKKOXA8fs7X_K7OUe5SiSdSVyIhxDw4Y1IjoFJStik16nMyiexe9xXIXCHrNtHpPzJ_eY-6l5G_JuZA_jtt3X4M5qs1ZfTn69y1WQizLU3w1SsHXq4H61siA5myqT5ZFnKlDUaTpy5BXb5hESclUSQrEJ0WHM=> . Et, en Francais (PDF) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J92OmI2Cz_wO5BsQGnxEgc_EHoQjikBialGwFU1p9XxnNNCvUrupkm-9TdQezYi11pcd_vkEs-Rx2NEhjzhfxF1rHy_12Iqoqv9GRnI-dn0NKxrxiyB3-06lAyyF7miBdo0bBQjZVyTX-SivzZdZsoC8> . Patent Play


In "The Patent, Used as a Sword," New York Times reporters profile the use of patents in the tech business. Stat from the article: "In the smartphone industry alone, according to a Stanford University analysis, as much as $20 billion was spent on patent litigation and patent purchases in the last two years - an amount equal to eight Mars rover missions. Last year, for the first time, spending by Apple and Google on patent lawsuits and unusually big-dollar patent purchases exceeded spending on research and development of new products, according to public filings." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J90b0VmJEjFktU9OqNjTkWigz7hrs42EoCLwZwyMyMq4fyW25ygUoUO5Ajx_aX0vqrZ4CoxxEJDg1-vSQCBmFSiXXHDRzQRUjgjJuRJEipl29TGRKx4cTMRrVUPNGPp2HvRefQTk1BdYc8Z-gGK35dxF46eTiiw7k56CQoCX8JSG1uQv_ijxZ7m6rq33lqC4plzyVn4I2NFOsBy45aEsEudkswKcoik2Kk0=>  And then, there's a celebration of the "creative act of copying" in Fast Company here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J91aKHdfGaRuXM-xuLSA0PmYB-KHmDBewMGcJJAyIN5vD6QgyW2WT3mmY3NGQEZ973LHI4fMc_dHHp_1xj-uYHMZcImzfTjGmIzgFwNl13Qoutv7_XrTv7tAP69_Wi0Dyq8dOY-rFPrQWK2zDYbF1lhDEaZssiVVek2pvsmJ9Xwos68Us-6FWQpAXJpDxJm37ac=> . 


Targeting Klout


Sounds like Facebook Ads API partner Social Code (AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J92PqcSWyviKFYldVz7u3C8N4lUTww-QQswimPpBp7z3ZAdYulm_dQUBBESrwauLeS7IxcL90PXwY155QRxkwx69wSzaonu79SBLMxYIvDz_YyPoG7-ycz0EOHPetPck4AXs4qcyUZn6TbqqrDOYfmL_HsIGfA84yd2GK2M_sMns6u4cAcGHu2QfcfrTLVru8N3Dg-UEyFvzyemyp6iYeuKl> &A) has created its own version of Klout targeting for social ads. From the release: "With 'Social Influencer Targeting,' for the first time, advertisers can reach users who are most likely to respond and engage on the brand's behalf, driving social recommendations and valuable earned media,' said Laura O'Shaughnessy, CEO of [Washington Post Co.-owned] SocialCode. 'Our research shows that each engagement results in 38 earned impressions, highlighting the importance of targeting and cultivating an engaged community.' Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J93SBMfLnEz3YerlWMFW5ta1U3fiMfEd6wpKI4c1B1XrIRle5KsG0V3ydAKXrsFhSGvrMKESj-4febuNYmIHe0VNnfyj-H5KRoPyrRip0cvj_S8qgkMZTMMxs7ZR3ZODo_sNRIdSXyFc9Ji1hTMKryW7> 
 
Preemptive Acqui-hiring


Second-hand clothing marketplace Twice has a novel approach to recruiting talent, offering $1 million to buy any company seed funded by Y Combinator, 500 Startups or TechStars. The idea, as TechCrunch's Sarah Perez reports, is to capitalize on the tougher fundraising environment. "Because of the glut of startups raising seed and angel funding, some are now struggling to raise a Series A round. But Twice is also hoping to take advantage of a more common problem startups face: the majority of these companies simply fail." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001XQpOiOs7J90CQTn18uJhPngMEWpsULCJjxDZpg6YVeKkz1yzS29WfLwWjmT2rGpfhxT1nvyTxS67cg9E1Xj1NnqlDU82nJnZx2nfSmqPY3EavKyjEetz6G_i_WbRVmlpGZ3n8xHr_fx634vv9CKR8_ukNHV8Y5tItbpm_EWUXEz63qd3JZkv3kMbx4SRKC9T8rDApdVoUM2gkk4aY9byOGA2jOewauKkcmVcjfzl6Y-fKJlOneva4XackuLhJ8Iau2rv_bfoCoJAuZQk_WszW_VVYmlFXZW2>  Will we see similar efforts to pick off ad tech startup talent?

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email? Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001IrPhGEaOWN0iugoqw3udE58D64c4MVtGsedwy9nCxGaYp-zZePVxqUyRNE0d1YlvOn0N8phNqZHp79-uDuMrtOd7mht8MROUtRfw_gXHdS_yTOMRbEfkPyQQW1rbLs3k12uQrXpmWHw=> .

 

Where's Tumblr's Ad Net?


Amid all the big conferences and big parties associated with New York's annual Advertising Week, there's the big complaints about big frustrations. Among the many cavils catalogued by Adweek's Mike Shields is the impatience with Tumblr's still-emerging marketing offerings. "This is a very visual medium," said Danielle Strle, Tumblr's director of product & partnerships. Shields adds, "If I'm a brand like Coke or Absolut or something, I'm way more excited about Tumblr than Facebook. So why doesn't Tumblr roll out an ad network?" Why indeed. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001IrPhGEaOWN3-pYtTGnOg7upAAXg5gz1vdxPJ9_yYrS9HZsU_bxTE5J5YnQDX3LD8eUVJWGl53PwzDIMIg057SpcbIGVJfz9dDEPH64EQEK3ex5IiTPm_jBubWxJHZYe0FtE6w_tAh-0BhJUAf-x417Gzl11_7iLs-698B_HRTCcWgzSrcafxcvB9UPizs0m0> . 


Acxiom Agnostic


ClickZ's Kate Kaye catches up with Acxiom and its CMO Tim Suther during Advertising Week in NYC last week. Suther talks about this company's cross-channel ad targeting vision and notes the importance of partnership. Kaye writes, "Acxiom also works with DSPs and agencies - working with them in conjunction with their trading desks, for instance. 'We view all of these companies as partners,' said Suther, stressing the fact that the company has no stake in media outlets chosen by ad clients." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001IrPhGEaOWN0SvHXBHHEQ3FG7HNuZktEwwQ3-i_sRCykon7pUHYtCvt8B4MSL0z1HZfe9OFczdPCKxeaMd56AnmtKjS9n6SV-QOXmMVruFK9URBW8ABjqY2ACIm6_w_YpeOGXFJtD5vo2rO0KsnYZECpknBXpcKhhgqRRiqBt6GhANwbJaMjHxAuyCma-oBQNiV0NMSOpFYhWeZLzyAKNbw==>  


Facebook Retargeting Made Easy


Perfect Audience, a retargeting specialist that works with small agencies, is the latest startup to hitch its wagon to Facebook Exchange. The Chicago-based company has raised a $1.1 million round to build up its technology operations, Techcrunch's Anthony Ha reports. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001IrPhGEaOWN16pQfLpFaceRERtKiPDyeVVNnYbW_B0Fb1NRmgPp_AqjtJmKy1gr1h5gKob49sCkmNRn2IaneyOcpJto2sdFR78I_2-JH8kZeujFSQ_aDNzdhvzE_nmgl1-4oWbEyYeRZC865mpkaqQ6tV16z5Wmz3TZqqCQnFyqY=>  (Perfect Audience's hometown paper, The Sun-Times, has more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001IrPhGEaOWN2Jst8LE_jlc4q4ONkmi7XhluHO-5clD5yw0bOouW6iOUMyVUpCYNHfGH48Cnw5LQALwExjrbl7J9eWUly2DHSF6DuN5scbnVs8kA-5TPjoxfh3RYZo2kDUSR0nW68pOlw_hRNURGs9xXN_QiX8p7B7dwQJa_2KTfDAJfDBbMreaXh9sJ39N9Q-i_AjepXb6MQMr__Z-Yf4mw==> .). Perfect Audience's co-founder and President Brad Flora tells Ha that it usually takes a few days to learn how to use most Facebook Exchange products, and there's often a minimum ad buy. "With Perfect Audience, on the other hand, anyone can run a campaign of any size," Ha writes. "You just create or upload the ad, fill out a form with the basic campaign information, provide a credit card, and you're good to go." 


Exchange IPO


OpenX CEO Tim Cadogan discusses his company's future with The Business Insider's Jim Edwards who writes, "In Q4 2011 [Cadogan] reported an annual revenue run rate of greater than $100 million, and that OpenX was profitable. That one-off note was interpreted by many as testing the water for an IPO, but Cadogan hasn't added to it since. Now, Cadogan says, 'we're well ahead of that today ... and we've continued in that vein.'" Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001IrPhGEaOWN1CnDefdzt28uypQ3I5KdQrJfYp0dbGAnUs9ru73y0PlkPRHU3_Ji5lo2lG6hj7vSdGScqd7yZb_BbbTFREQFqZluEQP0iIF7OoUbGMQZRkjleiwmtV1LH0NaphOJXi1yTFyf-OmypnIK10RWqoEIsR49hMt0jrXyfa3tuAYl2WDQ==>  


FBX Ad Sizes


Triggit CEO Zach Coelius keeps preaching the gospel of Facebook Exchange, telling AllThingsD's Peter Kafka why it's a powerful opportunity. Challenged by Kafka on the weak creative palette, he says, "The ad units are smaller than some of the others that we have, and if they were bigger they would work better. But they're definitely not limited, and they're not working poorly. They're working incredibly well. I could only imagine what we could do if they gave us a bigger canvas to paint on." More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001IrPhGEaOWN3AGLIkwnyjgrdsam2-7mCFXMJkIpqBbkFLl6mjRJVRMqBcrJ2WVDo_o7-gZbnY8SltT5EpfjepPUVdozpX_gwRgZFYqdaoR3A-rOnh9_wc6r6kP2ttEAsiB_LWeImPJfIMskCRjnHM4aga-g3cRtc_8rf2a6mykYHeEzL-QumF7JlVk1-KZ6-ezdfXVohunwrLoGWR6vL4t0c-HZe9BW_EhiIKRNu034c=>

Criteo's Data Story


Criteo talks attribution and data complexity in a Q&A on eConsultancy. "As an industry we often make display seem unnecessarily complex," says Michael Steckler, MD Northern Europe. "Ultimately knowing the most important data that drives greater user experience and ultimately more sales is where advertisers should focus. However we are now in a world where there is an inordinate amount of data to dissect. This takes time, investment and real technology that can automatically make decisions based on a myriad of factors." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001IrPhGEaOWN3w5DQKSZeJ7DBXvNgGesSxQMGrUPdXhAGjgOGUqr2jTCHs0O9s47E-oBCWTKeHhAizY8UkzVaj-5u9i0fGFN6EdNKJU5eolfV7jH449QVldwV3FW8d-TB88DbMJXfs3SKL-1j7MPEH1z9ddC4liFExtfuiJVaeLQcxHIjjDZpEmPXJ-W8BJcNCb7kpjEbBHeR71mFW7wyMvgjkZNENU0GxLqSB3Xpkj9m38aMkPCpLVQ==>

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email? Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmqz48e0sDKwIBr8KW45fZlkLF6soKtO1EXIRfAHXXYRDr5YMpC4A5zhztpPEkuzmAi4xWS98EDEKFCx3hQSvHMdwtJ95-Ak8Hs9dZRsAQ2NfxQ_DLxckyXiU4C2M4pe6oM=> .

 

A Billion Social Creatures


Facebook's billion-user milestone no less remarkable for having been long expected. But it may have overshadowed an even more amazing stat: The company now reaches 600 million users on mobile alone. Despite growth in mobile Sponsored Stories, Facebook is still seeking a proper way to monetize this ballooning channel. Greg Sterling, writing on his Screenwerk blog, argues the big value in mobile is around SMBs, and Facebook is falling way short. "Until the company can bring structured local and mobile 'utility' to Facebook users it will have difficulty across the board in monetizing SMBs or delivering real value to local consumers." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmoZDhz_-WNo3JYyeNXvsg6zW7O6dDM6hiJ5_HMnkcOLWghA79lmj1ZkJDAshCCjnZDoevSNYMn12tWFzRuuxxdImpjxbSg8UyaYuLLVPrs4BaxTV09A31taVjsexsismP1D4rwIo5P_gMKItKZu5zuJmWg7s-vVP97pkIbXE7wBr0Ky5mdkqmkQT5V5j2MdHqBjGEUi9_-wZw==>  Or read Facebook's blog post.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmqCSXMqOvHI3NeVmGYQmervJly0ibmrOXNdCZ1dEQPL-viVcMFbDwGvO7N9SlY4h9WtoCH7xkdLmFqLDOczvR04EXp30b3vkUQulS5Sd2lc8Z7SuKGq0zqzh8YbfCDzwkyZXfJUUP_ANaotcZS8WQNLqu_9E9H9y1E=> 


Privacy, Ads, Facebook


Privacy Choice's Jim Brock takes Facebook to task on his company's blog saying that the social giant "shows little interest in the industry's privacy initiative." He offers four ways, in particular, including, "They don't show the ad-choices icon. The icon is supposed to be a universal signal to consumers that their behavioral information is in play with an ad, so they get why it may feel creepy and can easily opt-out..." Native "ad choices" icon to come? Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmrBc6148hwbTc_Avbk1T-G4ijhgdYz9slguq-O5kDB35Vtc2D3aOq_1Css0V2rR6s40Kt89ldnfddANT800NSW6JxWJJkGlDzDkQ1er6-8SAMEONCnFNOeTYgn5zKHz4JIhZQgpo2db-fuPIP5_5WSR832n44A5W_a4bTxlYC5MgS6zFKunRqFqN4bsoiglJcBhcnG3Dc4ObrTjaagpI7px-tRBvjl6El0r4rNmygWCrA==> . 


Hispanic Private Exchange


On Portada, news of expansion of Orange Ad Market's exchange footprint takes centerstage. The company said that AppNexus will power a private exchange intended to provide real-time biddable access to U.S. Hispanic audience. Giuliano Stiglitz, CEO Orange Advertising Americas also tells Portada, "Orange Advertising will stop using other Ad-Exchanges (like Yahoo's Right Media): "From now on we will only use our own exchange for that part of our inventory which we intent to sell on an RTB basis. Our main business remains guaranteed buys of premium inventory. Despite the fast growth of RTB we still believe very much in the guaranteed model." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmpVorpUP10RK-m0ZHXt39Q9G6zToEx9gDesIoQxS5OFtLD_9kU60IqyR2p48Lvz2AbGdSPePhEAEnOqn-eKBHM_4KH7ICCo0nCy6qgc44Y1OO926eOmWs6WNDdH73dSsBk38pteeOmfeilpmG1wDKxM>  


Agencies Vs Procurement


Ad holding company CEO Miles Nadal of MDC Partners decried the continued propagation of procurement on the client-side in an appearance at an Advertising Week event. MediaPost's David Goetzl quotes Nadal, "The client procurement activity barely allows you to make a reasonable rate of return, let alone having sufficient incremental dollars to be able to invest in R&D." Read more about agencies' procurement perceptions. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmpDrscJrO9OP66pm7Ad86v0c_nqAaxjXEze9S6Um5iKPJazhQHjhAnBX9Xs1BLPsnXbIe0rT5xk_1b6Sx6vj0EEJLAb5WPvhmLuy1z24SvUMYB6NVGYlZfXCxzfnCEZcFb66tQdvLPqyfiZbl1TjU3_JLSmE_FNr25pqBS837EP-etTEIcXJeg5yLPkKZkrXLJBUBVW1a-1VoyllE2c-htpaFq4FlSgaIo=>  


Multiple Screens, Stories


With consumers glued to various screens, often at the same time, the content business, from advertising to programming, will have to adjust to what Rishad Tobaccowala, VivaKi's chief strategy and innovation officer of VivaKi, figures is a "ninety-degree arc" between the horizontal and the vertical screens. Writing on his personal blog, Re-inventing, he says, "Marketers will have to learn how to tell stories using multiple screens. They will also have the ability to enhance storytelling and data gathering and collapse the funnel from awareness to transaction." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmpACw8xuE9mGS5UDEWukiB6-HJmj9tocg5c4SxvhbSstlUnkAT995Hyw_vSh_n14w2R_TXLwdXMTAgsgJtMsAZwanPwFaDDh_KD9jcYMFD06AI9QZOB1u1IAxn85DIV5zXt7XwG_ML7zMuZW7jnJ8TIJT8zhKC4JwiH8eFRSgkxPA==> .

More DSPs The Better


Rubicon Project's Jay Sears interviews Omnicom/Annalect's Scott Hagedorn on the Rubicon Project blog. Hagedorn discusses his unit's trading desk - Accuen - strategy, "Annalect and Accuen believe that a multiple DSP approach is the right one for a client. After doing quite a bit of research, I believe that the inventory footprints are very different with each DSP. It's all about the reach." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmrCSnrRhrC0t7DGPZ0BtFwGPQ3QZD2g-K4tEdzxO5qzbQ4N-t7ALOS_eJA8LohUhoA5Pa7XueOgbphftcEGFd-fo6lzRF4vkVxlMwZDsrTX_JVcgGr-hYn8K9X2zhvbiWzSMxVH-kVeY3j6kqr1bqOee1E4PNzh5DKRMFhypXVnkHAlgg-PLheY875Ny4oMJt_eHNCloaMYqpqYA0BuNwHU>  


Streaming Videos 'R Us


The blurring lines between marketers and media producers, e-commerce and branded entertainment is the newest hope for struggling big box retailer Toys 'R Us, which is in the process of launching its own streaming video service to better compete against the likes of Amazon, the WSJ's Melodie Warner reports. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmqUd9_pV9oz9XXwSdZYIilxow7aygd_a4G7XpR9hCe_WOYf9Y4lY2lPVXC-bVCpzMs-bN-s07tJhcuNiOg65h843SjzoIzGLFJHQtMCMco0Tw9xXzq5ic_sT2jrTbF411a8BgZkufm1OQlIqYER5QBBz25LtocgJEtLptVvsPlXqL59SoYEFB12> . The service is being powered by Rovi Corp. in collaboration with Adobe. 


No 'Race To The Bottom'


Many major publishers still have lingering fears that RTB really means a "race to the bottom" in terms of premium ad pricing. Andrew Casale, VP of strategy for Casale Media, writes in The Makegood that publishers should seek multiple bids per impression from demand side platforms as a way to get the prices they want. "If buyers and sellers look at multiple bids per impression as a creative opportunity instead of just a means to increase clearing prices, this could reinvent the entire buy-sell process in RTB. This could potentially unlock more brand dollars and, in turn, make RTB a more effective part of ad sales." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmrj3J1LUrchxrpRluMGimmTWEiMhjAnYUa9AM9Zflxa0C-cAp4wp7w-VdG3O4qs8uB4tR5UBf3M2Ni7M-3RTt5LS3sr3H59pktpmtnEYIhkEdSlAjjgAPIiyfaGmbkIJSIVrKWXpHfm3lyX3X6N2d749Iq7eoK5ivKGGwipqZPUyVDw5ssQl_CTsTWOdv8-bV4=> . 


'Preferred' by Tumblr


These days you're not a real player in social until you have a vendor ecosystem. Tumblr jumps on the bandwagon by granting "preferred analytics provider" designation to Union Metrics, which measures social trends and buzz for a brand clientele. AllThingsD's Liz Gannes writes, "What's interesting about this idea is how late it's coming about relative to Tumblr's popularity - especially considering Twitter's developer ecosystem has become so fraught." Read more.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ubwfqNy-tmrpaCIXxok86Hv5XtE-6INP2h2thw1gtOh5xZNOlVAzrrC_Cf9FGleR7_hxRHFxu5Hmw6lqvlHxl-5sBwpQcfapUTm6DzYMMBlH-Bf4ZW0Vfyek6aVqu8LZaD_UGbtfmDCSTAi63PJjN4obdMWTmYXRWILzg7J0CC0_u8dCBLyVpV8fsdPpEi3_vAvWBIUscTs=>

Surveying The Twitter


Twitter announced yesterday that, with the help of Nielsen, it would let brands survey Twitter users regarding promoted tweet campaigns. Twitter VP of Brand Strategy Joel Lunenfeld discusses the implementation in a Twitter Ads blog post, "This is a native experience for the user, and we believe it will give brands better insights to determine purchase intent, overall awareness, and other advertising metrics and analytics that can lead to greater engagement on Twitter." Read the post <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o9wbMqMdpGLNRR_a4WHwFAThgPIP5ivGyDJohfX-EOx_6Fja64kEEEvkqMrUcXWxqYZ39HFu8dgRZ6suLWSHsnSiOFk8KIRtTN0tr_5vp9EGkCtbt8bryKLxaL6ARsEzDqAZquxHIy0hO76q38lfm9RM6ronrBaRZiLEDGjl9RbWxspgJWxZyVL> . That's nice.. but, I keep waiting for something bigger from Twitter. How about positioning it as a survey that leverages the Twitter user base and Twitter targeting to show cross-channel brand lift? Twitter is a pulsing feedback machine - seems like there's bigger fish to fry than just measuring the efficacy of Promoted Tweets. More from Kate Kaye on ClickZ. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o84aaAGl8Zei6cRXE0XSsZa_i1S504bxmNriUb3obzvT_O2agnrBnq25gZOsa8MI0ydTmc6cvm4VdUASPeS5k8OdY7wgL6ToT9NiY99vLNEnTk2PpbSUxU4r7yY4AyikIJwdy5EwY_intL4JAhk1_VWx-3LvUDSQxh4c81W36g_4lQNfE8eHRk_fpWhx5Op2PTjDnd3RB_HryAHCxfEkjYk>  


Agency Dollar


It's no secret IPG's Mediabrands wants performance-based pay, or that it has met with some push-back and inertia. As reported by Mediapost's Steve McClellan, "The agency encountered two major obstacles on the analytics side of its business that blocked the development of viable pay-for-performance models." Huw Griffiths, an analytics exec with Mediabrands' UM, told an audience at Advertising Week that a lot of the data that needed to be analyzed was 'siloed and disconnected,' he said. And some of the data wasn't granular enough to provide the kinds of insights the agency felt were necessary to devise new compensation schemes." Read more.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o95vcIX83MG564YgmxAENvsIXoFKLNTLzvmufT_KHjt8yZ8RHWQWITk4UySul1kiXd3UmPcSRTnrB1laP-1N_Q6-e9i1EoQv92MOKOFWFU3J9RdbORktKO1cVLXO-vE5RJ20DOjPdLiL_7ig0gmrXBcwwGUOb5LhRxg4eITng9aHncQQjtOSeAFHEBbHwC3L13hzj5mZvMkT9DA1wSUqqNWvsEHvFkqzMBeKN_IXox1hSjL59XyarK9> 


Data-Driven Ads


Google continues to merge its Google Analytics and AdWords products as the company discussed the new features in a blog post yesterday, "After setting up AdWords to import your Google Analytics data <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o-ave6a5XcbDBVBYhVura-KZVdzlcJbwPv6gZRA1H7Ei9d3t0gXHQn-WiwWXrd94RK-GjU7-1YA_9bVhehFQVfxGxb9efDyk3aEGr6k-LF1fh0xmgRxnp3BM_IUjomYY7mjrk1dWs7WakNY3KhGRQsGfRZCmNyuoZligqvpRe0XxLqKmoTowPP5> , you'll have access to key metrics like Bounce Rate, Pages Per Visit, and Average Visit Duration directly in the AdWords interface." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o88fpAVqptgzARIgPe9QhZkLtmn0uJFwsEocv5WVnush7jRqVUI48oSxyBbYASljtgQIWSDeEygU4Lc7nFyJf-MFQK_B9hxNG_-_ORRPvuuWVteESCFxA1VgA-CbcqhAYd4iyVmbzQKkCKpNfvj_MCw5csSQicruWlQaKRROy0tuTLnbStqFYor> . This follows the integration of retargeting capabilities into GA <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o89NRPDqOOxeSQy4FuICpCM-e4--B17JXzzr5mhbQFHwUkfznrwbysyvwLRL8gmnsiKnhg6mUAStR7yxt01uz8hK5IxABIsoYmIn_hEU66T9xn2QLpOdNcrICZYz17xyuVonvcrZPB51bGWUe2eJbmC> . 


The Biddable Media Engineer


The Media Kitchen's Barry Lowenthal announces the creation of a new role at his agency on MediaPost. He writes, "While the technology continues to improve and more inventory sources are lit up for RTB, we can begin improving performance by sharing data. Search data can help us identify different data segments to buy on the exchanges and vice versa. As a result, we see the need to create a bridge -- and that person is called a Biddable Media Engineer." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o9aUAsosVvlXEIsIx6oNAteOcHYfbTPQrszSyizQ-w5hn7GOPEdgGPsYpzjZo0Hi47a3eKbjVTLimBXUyiXNDl7d8tz3MmS4Q-VWLxbKFPnrPwNgQEzBjuUVhwAHLbNd2IO6qMEqZ7teRjD8q7Ipt8C-pnLRBAg8D-HLu2Pc7KCKP-Qdj4cq1FbFDoecnURG9Z5J7BjQ45Fz8wToRTqiBHp>  


Sell Your Own Data


If it's true that two-thirds of consumers don't want advertisers surreptitiously monitoring their web activity, perhaps they would be amenable to selling their personal data directly. That's the proposition of ad tech startup Enliken <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o9CK4fuJx7t2g0AoEPT8cs_V63KWTSw5bnWom_W-5Zp8liGHDNRBFlIQvOYj3pnoWatRydLaWKzTfqdk4utIkQm0oU52NMn7xQ=> . (AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o9Ry2Q7w_tygmFRqDsOU01kvhQbgSPMK0OkeUI9oNv5LQyyhje_lIpvj3M5_s0DjjO9ni2E_aZaGQgW6YAW55kUvaqYX8YmPrrRFdAcE5wBYCnR7WbEuMQejdRxhFeEPcnuQTEMN4r7nbxwZujYubcb3oyu0Gt5AhlaXbv21LaBHDrSAbjmOp9aSpiDHbwS32g7nXcL0Eif69uQiC8hoUf1> &A from August). In a profile by the NYT's Jessica Bruder, founder Marc Guldimann says, "When you empower people to control something, you make them feel good. It's a chemical reaction in their head. They're like, 'This makes me feel great. I'm going to share more information because I feel in control.'" Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o_umDzz5OXwU7U4VEgeOsmEH9nDqFvRwYDp5S4cJ8q6buFi495-SSKjQpT2_-kKw-X_QajN7Daw_gSTzOT0T7z7u9fyiw_mZwUCpKIRyEbXAuLsDNihT_4JyMUK9t3HzxAdxDfhJ9-jPwQJZTlSKTDIqgOPGdn5d7i_bqMPwRtIO6sGrA8BlmMNMvBGIlFYUw4=> . 


Sponsor Message: 
Artificial Intelligence  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o9cBDk9LHbqs3o1QkvEo0v0EDQIYO92sbNmfqIruSuxa7iKX1Yv3tvLP9g0G39ct-LQFq6-3k8Q_sbuRXdx8_PZK8BvUwpUJJjs2bC8rgnj4M1SSDUtILDflRT0oD_xFn0=> + Big Data =

Connected TV KC


Unnerved by the possibility that Google could swamp them in Kansas City - and elsewhere - with its ominous-sounding dark fiber initiative, AT&T and Time Warner want the same incentives that Google received from the city of Kansas City to set up its high speed network. The WSJ explains, "Among the sweeteners granted Google by both cities are free office space and free power for Google's equipment, according to the agreement on file with the cities. The company also gets the use of all the cities' 'assets and infrastructure' -including fiber, buildings, land and computer tools, for no charge. Both cities are even providing Google a team of government employees 'dedicated to the project.'" Rumors about free steaks abound, too. Read more (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o93txDD1qEgWtbDdLtg-F8LsUxhwRvsriELgXsxjo-s8cyzGLKJxzKb_QZgX8LjyZzhS-dTYOFkFr7JxKVKw8JsyEwUpsXsK3bAwM39cAX4K08Ain-PwnApypteKPlJ5XpwvewTtiIbsKcTzWTHfaH4Zo13ILUFEynOmLrw1nkC_U--R32d2gmP> . 


Salve The Sales Leader


Doug Weaver consoles the sales leader beseiged by acronyms and stacks on his Upstream Group blog, " ...Tech vendors and other experts have consistently piled more and more new flavors into the freezer: last week optimization was the thing....then RTB alignment with Demand Side Platforms...today viewability...and on and on. To the sales leader - who deals with a complex set of shifting demands that span revenue, customization, personnel, channel conflict - it can all seem disingenuous and confused." He offers the three C's as an antidote. Get comfortably numb. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o_mX-HdQDd98uvwWXBXvH4r9sPNJjcErU8xsUBA5gfb4qVCv6UM720V1wh-ISS1tETsejcxl3azBTLoaw_8x7Q5qV8U6es7dbpESHIG3jdhlOBJzTWQ4W2yD51xjsGyeCU6X4nB-wef8Q==>  


All Ads Must Be Viewable


Ari Brandt is tired of digital ad industry whining about online media not getting its proper due. Writing in Mediapost, the former Condé Nast exec and current head of social analytics provider Mediabrix says bluntly that the industry's direct response-focused measurements and paltry creative options have left online undeserving of premium budgets. He's the latest to propose "viewability" as the way to change marketers' minds. "I'm calling for us all to adopt viewable impressions, which will force the industry to stop commoditizing digital ads... this is still an issue today, some four years later, with a glut of premium and remnant inventory running through ad exchanges." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o8vA3fTRuC7SNq9T1LXQR3njKEgdzmpRa85A52ypPKGZNq7Uuq2hXH6Tm2_l4jkDu3Vzbx1A77WQlUZ5TVZc3CVLKMnL0MFbwzAISjpd_T3PBePdciuR7_FXmebYt7P8PqJyyKuNM6AR6Nlz7qW7Svo> . 


Shopping Carts Abandoned


Whatever the retail innovation, Amazon tends to get there first. Its synchronization of the mobile and desktop shopping cart is a great example with some ad implications to boot. eConsultancy's David Moth compares several UK brands and finds mobile shopping carts are, well, abandoned. More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rgFJwT4S3o-DOA9BeGmMhgc18fWdKFrPVBOX1m93gtqX9aEZvnji1iK2_Id7n2Z2UoAsD1Nv9TgFRiIq6gdRuGJEByk63TzXulpbosI2NG4G-TqC-m-Ai2-ARC6cOgRpkHgkuYr04ZSwZtZL3P1GoHYW1v3kJZy-ghpX5oDXTiZddZwq6BWJCMYXk5ELqeIdFmSmbS0mhh35HXi27P6uG8EMGFhQWtGQnoIk0gwBNk4=>

When you work with a number of partners and suddenly everyone starts playing favorites or limiting things for reasons that aren't entirely transparent to the broader marketplace, it's a disturbing place that it could go to..." *	Adobe Blows Its Stack, Unifies Ads and Analytics Products <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001o6sW3umaz3Jsag2XiWtOnmyIm2j7KH5KGQegCQNqAfOkMq1mQPneZRtqyvC48_h4gOLOGq96nPhf2RFT6_3CZCX9rc1waVII2WH1YZ7lBuQOCyRUNNFk1hSKuvJNb9f4uqJxzdJDNhonxucZ38drpPqPHxwrxoKUuJuyWpBi73avpBkUrg2ST89-l4RsFYZVGCRhqBejQkGNIvff4hNL0A==>  "Adobe has integrated two of its core digital marketing products - SiteCatalyst and AdLens (formerly Efficient Frontier)...The overall effect for marketers is 'much richer data sets to be used across search display and social advertising,' says Justin Merickel, an Adobe exec with oversight of ad product innovation..." (visit AdExchanger)

In terms of inventory classification, the goal here is to produce recommendations and help define more murky inventory channels. That's good for the industry. For companies like Google, we feel it reflects things that we've already put in place, such as investments to prevent malware and offering spam protection.'..." (visit AdExchanger)
